description:
Just half a block from Golden Gate Bakery, Yin Du is alwaaaays bustling. Expect to share your table with a cute granny and her all her grocery shopping bags because there are never enough seats! It's a tiny place with an equally tiny menu but the food is delectable.

I love ngau lam meen (HK beef brisket noodles) to death, and it's not easy to find a place in the bay that serves just this dish. Yin du is my go to place for this. If you get the beef brisket noodles with wontons, you're probably gonna get only 2 bits of beef. If you don't eat the odd bits and pieces of tendon and other indistinguishable cuts, you're gonna get 1 bit of beef. So, if you love the stewed beef brisket, I'd advise getting a side of the beef brisket. It costs as much as the bowl of noodles (or a little more) but you can be assured of a plate full of pickings! 

The charsiew rice is good too, and the curry fish balls are quite passable. Getting by with English alone you're gonna have to engage in some pointing and hand gestures, and come prepared with cash, it's cash only! 

Tip: Hollywood bakery is right next door if golden gate is closed and you want some asian pastries. Another busy location with lots of grannies and grandpas who will stare at you unabashedly as you walk in wondering what you're up to today. It's quite cute.
author: Su Lin Y.

description:
Look I'm going to be really honest. We found this place on yelp and the reviews were great. And we thought that it was gonna be a little bit better the wonton soup that we had didn't have much soup and the noodles were very soft actually too soft. The milk tea that we had was really good.

Also we had BBQ pork over rice but they forgot the barbecue sauce and the pork was very cold for some reason didn't really appreciate it. And to top it all off when we left the bill was good only spend about $22 for 2. We were arranging the tip when the lady asked us for a tip before we even tried so that was very rude and disrespectful. Coming from LA I wasn't expecting that We gave her two dollars and she still requesting more for her tip and we weren't understanding why after The food was cold noodles were not good  just don't go here . It's not cool
author: Edwin S.

description:
3.5 stars. If you're craving wonton noodles... you guessed it, this place hits the spot. Small family-run business, and we were lucky when peering in after their business hours, the business owner saw us and summoned us in. 

Braised beef wonton & duck wonton for $13. Very good prices! The wontons were very delicious and juicy. The braised beef was tender and much better than the duck. The duck only came with three pieces :( Maybe because they were closing, and that was the only amount they were left with. LOTS of noodles in comparison to the wontons/meat.

Solid noodle place around the area.
author: Vickie Z.

description:
Good for quick - cheap lunch of Wonton & Noodle soup. 
They were pretty busy, but don't be shy and just ask to share a table, or the lady will ask someone for you.  Expect moderately fast, inexpensive, and decent wonton.  The broth is moderately clear, but about what one makes at home.  Overall fairly clean, worth stopping in if you're here and hankering for wonton noodle soup.
author: Chris G.

description:
Fast, cheap, and no frills. Bring cash!

Bowls are slightly smaller than you'd expect of a noodle place (not as big as Hy Ki Mi Jia's), but was filling enough for me. Shrimp/pork wontons and duck pieces were juicy and flavorful. Noodles were firm-ish can came with a fragrant broth. 

Sometimes you'll have to sit with random people at a table because of limited seating but that is fine; usual customers are local chinatown aunties/uncles. 

Definitely not a lot of menu variety but it was yummy!
author: Lydia Z.

description:
You don't come here for the service. What you do come here for is quick, easy, yummy, and DANG CHEAP (but still extremely good) noodles. 

The service wasn't friendly, but we did get tea right when we sat down which was nice. 

I'd recommend the wonton noodle (no soup) as well as the wonton soup noodle with BBQ pork. Both were $5.75. Best money I've spent in a LONG time. Soup was rich, but not salty. Wontons were hearty, filled with meat. Noodles had good consistency. 

Come to this hidden gem/hole-in-the-wall for the best priced noodles in SF Chinatown. 

*also it's cash-only, which isn't bad considering how little it can cost to eat here! It does also close at 6:30 PM I believe, so it's mainly a lunch place.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
If you want definitively friendly service, eat elsewhere. What they lack in service, they make up for quality and value. To me they didn't seem rude, but maybe it's a cultural thing that I'm just used to. 

Come here for the great food for hella affordable prices. Stopped in for lunch today and tried the beef brisket noodles with flat rice noodles.. pretty great. The broth was so flavorful and it was a great portion size. After tip, I spent $9 for a tasty & filling lunch. 

- know what you want to order ahead of time or be capable of making a decision quickly
- cash only
author: Jeanine S.

description:
OK noodle place. Cheap and decent quantity/quality.

Service is a bit curt, but not rude. Their steamed tripe is pretty decent. Wontons are ok as well.

Cash only.
author: Jimmy S.

description:
It's a very hidden joint in Chinatown in SF. When I first walked inside, I was not greeted or acknowledged by the ladies that is running the show. I went straight to the register to order my food and the lady instantly spoke to me in Cantonese which I had no clue what she was saying. I ordered my food which is the brisket and wonton noodles, went back to a table and sat down. 

The food than was brought out to me, looks very yummy and a lot for only $5.75. Which was great. The texture of the soup is very good, not greasy. The meat was tender and the wonton have great seasoned and flavors. I really like it a lot! 

When I went to pay for my bill, the lady demanded that I give her tip and I told her I had placed it on table. She was not happy and demanded I go to the table and take the tip money and hand it to her. Very rude and greedy. Even though the food is good, this is no way to treat a paying customer. Tip is not a must but it's something you earn. Would I give them another chance if I go back to SF? I would because of the food.
author: Annie N.

description:
I recommend this place if you want to spend a cheap lunch in Chinatown and if you don't feel like eating dimsum or buns. Dimsum would be similar price and buns would definitely be cheaper.

I came here twice and both times were to-go orders. It is very quick since they only have a couple of items on their menu so no need to call in or wait a long time if you are just getting a to-go order.

I tried the beef brisket rice noodle and wonton noodle soup.

I really enjoy the beef brisket. It is really tender and flavorful with the gravy. The rice noodle seems too soft and slippery like it was overcooked. The wontons are good. It comes with six wontons and the egg noodle is better than the rice noodle. Each bowl also comes with two yao-choy.

The soup is probably MSG soup. For the beef brisket and wonton, my total was $12.50. Maybe they charged me more because my order was to-go or they charged me for tax because according to the prices on the menu, it would've only been $5 for wonton noodle soup and $5.75 for beef brisket which will come up with a total of $10.75.

Overall, the food is good but don't expect for high quality food here!
author: Allie Y.

description: great no frills Cantonese comfort food.  Bowls of noodles and congee, all made quickly and authentic.
author: Tina M.

description:
The best beef brisket and tendon noodle in the Bay Area with good pricing - can't describe it in words.

The con is that you will need to sit with other people, that they're trying to maximize the number of customers at every single moment. However this is very usual in a famous Hong Kong cafe and it won't stop me from visiting this place.
author: Yuen Yung L.

description: Great place and great price too for noodle or rice. Noodle soup average is $5.50-$6.25 per bowl and portions is perfect. Wonton is great and they have noodle or rice noodle too. They have stew beef brisket or stew pig feet , definitely I will try next time. They closed on Wednesday. Daily close at 6:30 pm.
author: Ray K.

description: Went there 2 days in a row when we were in SF. As a native Cantonese, I would say this was the most authentic place I had ever been to in the west coast.
author: Ziran L.

description: Get the stewed beef brisket and wonton noodle soup ($6.25). The beef brisket is tender and flavorful.
author: Beth K.

description: BEWARE!!!!! dead cockroach found in beef stew noodle soup :0/  this was my go to place for beef stew noodle soup for the longest time. i am beyond disgusted and disappointed. makes me wonder how many insects i've consumed past years from this place :0(
author: Melanie Y.

description:
Today I was kinda in the mood for a good bowl of porridge.
I was walking by this place and saw the menu and decided to try this place.
I ordered pork liver & pork congee (porridge) $4.25
and pig's feet noodle $5.25

the porridge was good, the consistency was perfect.
the size was decent.
the pig's feet noodle was pretty bland.
the noodle was bland, the sauce on the pig was nothing to merit a second visit.
pretty cheap, but you get what you pay for.
author: Rudy H.

description: Fast and cheap... yeah. But you get what you paid for. The service is pretty bad and it's also pretty dirty. I got the beef/wonton combo noodle bowl. I really can't argue with the price, especially being in SF, CA but the taste...ehhhhhhhhhh it's aight. (this is also coming from a kid that had wonton and beef noodle soup growing up)
author: Jason L.

description:
Ok I put off writing this review so many times because I don't want people to know about this special gem!

My boyfriend and I love this place because apparently it reminds him of wonton noodles he had in Hong Kong and it's super authentic. The wonton skin was thin and filled with meat. Great prices at around ~$6 per bowl too.

Overall it's great value at a hole-in-the wall place. The staff isn't the most friendly but they're very efficient.
author: Alicia L.

description:
The best wonton noodle and beef brisket in Chinatown!

Seating is crowded though and you'll have to share a table frequently, so come here for the food, but don't expect quality Western style service.
author: Adrian L.

description:
This is my go-to cheap Chinese noodles place, and one of a few restaurants in Chinatown I actually frequent. The food is authentic and super cheap by SF standards. My favorite dish is the beef brisket Lai fun, which has always been consistently delish. In general the food is not super greasy or salty, which fits my taste preferences. Unfortunately I have run into a couple of instances where the non-soup dishes were obviously just heated up and still lukewarm :(

The service is typical Chinese, not very friendly, but super fast. Cash only!
author: Julie Z.

description:
$5.75 for a bowl of wonton noodles with braised beef? Yes please! I've had my share of amazing wonton noodles in my lifetime having spent my formative years in Hong Kong and this is probably as authentic as you can get outside of Asia. 

The broth was a bit on the light side, watered down a tad without an enormous amount of depth but the beef was tender and the wontons, albeit on the smaller side, added flavour to the entire dish. 

I'll probably choose the rice noodles over the egg noodles next time but it was a hearty bowl of food for a cold San Francisco day. Also ordered the curry fish balls ($5.00) which I would probably skip out on next time. Curry wasn't good at all and ridiculously overpriced for what you got. 

Protip: Cash only and keep in mind when it's busy you'll probably be eating with strangers, local style.
author: Eunah T.

description:
Overall great value for some tasty noodles and tender beef. This is a hole in the wall shop with an efficient and friendly staff. They can't be attentive, but what do you expect for a hole in the wall.

We tried the ho fun braised beef soup and wonton noodle soup. Preferred the ho fun as the egg noodles were a bit to thin and firm for my taste. I typically like the wider softer egg noodles. Braised beef was tender with nice pockets of tendon and fat. Wontons were tasty, but nothing to write home about. It's all about the braised beef here.
author: Mike P.

description:
Cash only. Closed Wednesdays.

Came here for another team lunch last Friday. We arrived around 11:45 and got seated a little after 12 for the 6 of us. That's not too bad.

My coworker recommended the stewed beef brisket & noodle soup (#8 on the menu), so that's what most of us ordered. For only $5.75, you get a delicious bowl of beef brisket soup with rice noodles. They don't skimp on the meat, which is super tender and flavored with all the right spices. 

The portion size isn't the biggest, but it does the job if you're just a little hungry. If you want a heftier portion, you can pay an additional dollar or two for extra rice noodles.

They have lots of other options on the menu too: lots of other noodle soup options as well as various congee and rice plate options. I'd love to come back and try some of these other option sometime!
author: Dianna H.

description: Yin Du, please don't go away any time soon. Chinatown is changing, but I hope joints like yours never do. Cash only, people, so make sure you have some on you. You're here for their tender yet springy beef brisket over noodles and wontons. Don't expect any sort of great service or ambiance. This is your classic noodle house with sticky chairs and tables and gruff Chinese ladies slinging your food. It's under $6 for a nice, big bowl of the good stuff, and your bowl comes out in less than 5 minutes after you order. I'm a little disappointed that nothing here is actually made in-house, but these guys do a great job with putting together a cheap, quality meal. Chinatown is losing these joints, and I'll be a sad man when they're all gone, but for now, my belly is happy.
author: Danny C.

description:
This is quite literally a whole in the wall, and not in a good way. 

There are roughly about 8 tables in this restaurant, and can fit up to 50-60 people in total. The kitchen is in the back, and you can see the chef making your food. I came around 1:00PM, a little after the typical lunch rush and didn't have to wait. It seems that the population who comes are all of the elderly, like their "go-to" spot for a wonton noodle fix. 

Two orders: Dry wonton noodles; and wonton noodle with beef stew. 
First off, the noodles here are pretty good. There's a bounce to each bite. HOWEVER, the portion is extremely small. While the price is decent for the type of food you're getting (~$5 for small wontons, noodles, and one veggie), it's a pretty small portion. 

The meat in the wonton of the dry noodles did not taste fresh. The beef tendons from the beef stew was tough, and the meat was also dense. Again, the beef portion was also VERY SMALL. 

Definitely would not recommend coming here when you're super hungry. But this can be a cute place for a 3PM afternoon snack.
author: Teresa C.

description:
I was really craving authentic wontons. 

Let's be clear, there is no ambience what to speak of here and most of the customers are legit Cantonese speaking and older.  However, they have enough English to get my order right.

The stewed beef and wonton noodle was Delish!  The stewed beef gravy really adds flavor to the soup so I can see how the plain soup would be too bland. The wontons were small, but tasty!

Hits the food spot! Just be prepared for typical HK street restaurant service. It'll seem like they're barking at you, and people will just shout orders/ request across the room.
author: Kathryn C.

description: Amazing place for wonton noodle soup.  The broth is flavorful and the noodles are cooked perfectly.  You can watch them make the wontons fresh.  Personal favorite is the beef stew with wonton noodle soup with the flat rice noodles.
author: Jason L.

description: My family recently discovered Yin Du and were so impressed that we visited twice in three days. Like many other cheap and delicious Chinese restaurants, the service is no-nonsense and brusque, the tables are invariably sticky, and the bathroom is questionable at best. The restaurant itself is tiny - I think there are 6 or 7 tables total and probably has seating for 20 people tops. They are definitely not shy about asking you to scoot over so that they can fit other diners at your table. Hopefully you don't mind eating with strangers! With all that said, I still highly recommend Yin Du! Where else are you going to get a gigantic bowl of tender beef brisket, wontons, fresh egg noodles, and flavorful soup for under $6? Do yourself and favor and order a portion of the tendon for the table - you get a massive plate of perfectly cooked tendon for $8 which you can then happily plop into your noodle bowl for an added oomph. I'm not sure what sauce they cook their meats in, but it's freakin addictive. You can add extra noodles for a buck, though I think the regular portion size is plenty. They have congee and rice options too, but glancing around it looks like everyone is here for the brisket and noodles. Oh, and it's half a block away from Golden Gate bakery, so you can stroll over and get an egg tart for dessert!
author: Justine L.

description:
Small shop but enough for a break and rest.
Price reasonable and good portion.  Clean rest room .
author: Winnie C.

description:
I wasn't expecting anything special out of this place, but it was pretty good. Since it's small inside, there will most likely be a wait if you go during lunch time. The noodles come out quick though, so if there's a line, it goes pretty quickly. When seated, you will have to squeeze yourself into a table that other people might already be sitting at. They want to seat as many customers as they can. 

I got the beef stew and wonton noodle soup with the flat rice noodles. Most of the flavor in the noodle soup came from the beef stew. It mixed in nicely with the soup, making the whole dish taste like oyster sauce. There was a handful of beef pieces and 3 or 4 small wontons. Even though the bowl they served the noodles in wasn't that big, they actually put a decent amount of noodles in there. If I happened to be the area, wanted Chinese noodle soup, and wanted something inexpensive, I'd come here again.
author: Lucinda H.

description:
Yin Du is one of two "traditional noodle house" in Chinatown that I've been to. This one is in the heart of Chinatown while Hon's is just a couple of blocks away. Yin Du is as traditional as you get. Let's start with the stinking open trash can on the pavement that welcomes you as you enter; the strong smell that hits you once you are inside; the busy ladies at the counter that ignore you till they finish whatever they are doing; the awkward look that you get when they hear that you want something to-go; the trepidation of sitting on one of the dirty sticky tables and finally the sigh of relief that slips your lips when you are finally able to leave with your order.

Well at least it's cheap. Wonton noodle soup will set you back by a humongous amount of $5.75. Extra noodles are another $1, another 25c for the container, another 10c for the bag fee, plus tax and you still haven't hit double digits. This has to be the saving grace, its dirt cheap.

Taste wise its fine. The noodles and broth are given in the same container so as long as you eat as soon as you reach home its fine, else these cheap noodles will suck up all the broth and become baby food. Wontons are also fine, not great but not bad either. It would be better to dine-in, which is exactly what I did during my second visit. Had a much better overall experience especially with the food, even though the serving size seemed a bit small. Overall it's not bad for a cheap fix, but almost on par with Hon's. For some reason that I'm still not clear on, I prefer to go to Hon's than come here, but both are the same in price and service.
author: Ahmad J.

description: Not the cleanest place in Chinatown but which restaurant is??? Found a hair today and before on previous orders I found a gnat. The food is standard but I feel I have enough business and in hopes they would step their game up but no. Last trip here
author: Tasha L.

description:
Stopped by for a quick lunch bite after running some errands; I was really craving jook. Came at noon and it was super busy, my boyfriend and I squeezed in to a table that soon had its six chairs filled by 3 different parties. 

I ordered boneless chicken congee (stomach virus recoveree), bf ordered roast duck noodles, and we shared gai lan with oyster sauce. Everything came out within 7 minutes: portions were hearty, flavors simple and fresh, and very reasonably priced (you will actually receive $5 worth of vegetables here). 

Overall, I would definitely duck back in here if I'm craving simple Cantonese food. Not for Yt people, we were the only non-Chinatown denizens in there and it does feel like a Chinatown restaurant (service is fast and loud, personal space is different than yt restaurants, etc). Remember, cash only.
author: Julia B.

description:
Good wonton noodles, but wontons are on the small side compared to their picture on the wall. 
Roast duck noodles only had 2 pieces of duck on top.  Beef brisket 牛腩is a bit too salty. 
There was a line when we arrived the restaurant on a Friday morning (11:30am) we waited for 10 minutes and shared a table with another couple.
author: Angel H.

description: Fun local place.  The noodles were delicious.  Cash only.  Not a tourist in the restaurant.
author: Jill P.

description: Another candidate of wonton battle royal in chinatown. Yin Du wonton clearly has better wonton than Hon wun tun, however Hon Wun Tun dumpling are ahead of Yin Du. As for price Yin Du is much cheaper. What  I dont like about Yin Du wonton noodle, is that they have store brought chili sauce.
author: Dan A.

description: This was in my dish. we spoke up and they were like oh it's okay it's from cleaning the dishes etc... they only offered to cover the one dish witch in any restaurant they would have covered the whole bill especially being under 25$. The food was good but after seeing that got really disgusted by there carelessness and they never apologized
author: Bella X.

description: I went here with my mom while we were touring around San Francisco for the day. All of a sudden we were in the mood for Chinese and went to Chinatown for a couple of hours. This place was on Yelp and I'm very happy we chose wisely. This place is a smaller type restaurant with a cash only policy, but their food is very flavorful and decently priced! I ended up getting the Dumpling noodle soup with beef brisket, while my mom got the beef brisket stewed with rice. Both meals were well prepared and very tasty! I'm still a sucker for the dumplings in seattle, but this place comes in close second! Would recommend!
author: Makio P.

description:
A pretty amazing deal to have a hearty and satisfying lunch in downtown San Francisco for $5.75 (+ tip).  Especially refreshing when old staples like Z&Y are getting more expensive and pulling tricks like charging for rice.  Just the right amount of food to fill you up, but not make you grossly full.

Stewed Beef Brisket & Wonton Noodle Soup: The broth was shocking complex and so tasty.  The wontons had a nice mix of ground pork and shrimp pieces, seemingly better quality than all those to-go dim place places.  I liked the chewy kinked noodles, they were very comforting.  The brisket was so soft and full of 5-spice goodness.  Some pieces were a tad too fatty for me but none of my dining mates seemed mind, so I'm probably just finicky about that.  For good measure there were two pieces of vegetable in there, so I felt healthy about it!
author: Adam B.

description: Good if you want cheap and mostly homemade food. I was able to see from my seat most of how they prepared the food. Fried rice was cooked homemade style, though they obviously had the meat and rice prepared already. Beef rice noodle soup was okay... couldn't see the preparation as much because it was more in the back. Noodles and soup were bland. Most of the flavor came from the wontons and the beef, which had been marinated in some corn starch, as it was gooey.
author: Lucy T.

description: Okay, I should've sampled this place a few more times before writing so enthusiastically about it. I didn't realize they have a hygiene problem until I came back on a Sunday and were given chopsticks that were greasy and a spoon with crusts on it! There were crusts on the handle of my teacup as well. I was so disgusted that I left without ordering anything. As much as I like their beef stew and wontons, I don't care for chewing on other people's leftovers and I will not come back again. Also notice their health inspection score is 71 which is only 1 point away from failing!
author: Carl W.

description: It was ok. The food wasn't bad but it wasn't good either. The service was bad though. I was about to order and they walked away in the middle of me talking and then they forced me to tip them. They were pretty rude and forceful about it so I just gave them a dollar. I wouldn't return to this place again. I would advise that you try another noodle place.
author: Kevin Y.

description:
Under $6 for a good bowl of wonton noodle soup. Can't really beat that value in the city!

The soup and the wontons were flavorful, and the beef brisket was tender. There was a good amount of tendon-y bits in the meat though, so if that's not your thing, I'd recommend getting another wonton noodle soup without the brisket.

One bowl will be enough for a small to average appetite, but if you can handle more, you might as well order two bowls. My boyfriend and I ordered two bowls each, plus a side of bok choy, and our total bill was still under $30. 

Service isn't fantastic, but that's kind of expected. Bring your Mandarin-speaking friend along, and you'll be better off (Thank you, Chinese boyfriend)
author: Sara L.

description:
During my family vacation to San Francisco in July, my father got a hankerin' for some congee. He was craving some seafood/fish congee which is how we ended up at Yin Du.

Now let me start off by saying we were on vacation and had sights we wanted to see so we started our day early. I learned that Chinese restaurants in SF are not open around 9 - which took my by surprise. Yin Du technically opened at 9:30 but their door was open so we asked if they would serve us early and kindly obliged without any malice that customers were there early.

While Yin Du didn't have any fish congee, we were more than satisfied with their Mixed Meat Congee and Pork Stomach Congee. We also had the Dry Wonton Noodle (comes with soup on the side) and Duck Wonton Noodle (in soup). I'm biased towards noodles with soup but Moms & my sister were very into the dry noodles.

Yin Du was so good that instead of trying a new Chinese breakfast place, we had Yin Du the next day too. It really reminded me of being in Taiwan and having a go-to noodle and breakfast spot. If my from across the sea parents approved that should tell you how good the food is here. PLUS shortly after opening at 9:30 there were others who came in that morning and ordered bowls of noodles for breakfast - a true testament to the tastiness of Yin Du.

If you're in San Francisco Chinatown definitely check out Yin Du!
author: Kim M.

description:
I come to YIn Du when I am feeling nostalgic about HK. The ladies who run the shop are so nice, they're like our aunties. They tease us, bring us delicious food, and make sure that we have a good time there. If you've been to HK, then you know that feeling of storeowners rushing you to finish your food and leave so they can serve more bowls to hungry folks. 

Yin Du however, makes you feel welcomed, not rushed, and happy. 

Come here if you want your beef brisket noodle fix, if you're in chinatown and want a cheap place (&declicious) to eat, or if you're hungover :D 

Beef Brisket is just bomb.com
I can't wait to go back and try the pork knuckles and tripe :P
author: Dana Z.

description:
CASH ONLY

Yin Du is a great place for lunch because their entire menu is inexpensive. Recently, I came here and tried their roast duck & won ton noodle soup. The wontons were small but delicious. The soup broth was flavorful without being too oily. I wish the roast duck portion size was bigger, but it's hard to complain when the noodle soup is only a little more than five dollars. 

There's often a line for this restaurant. Be prepared to seated at another table with customers, so you will share a table with strangers. The turnover of tables here is quick, so you don't have to wait too long for a seat.
author: Philip M.

description:
We were looking for a place to eat in Chinatown, and decided on this Cantonese restaurant after reading a list of positive reviews on Yelp. We quickly rushed over before closing time at 7pm, and were promptly seated by the kitchen. The hole in the wall, no frills décor included two rows of tables stacked vertically along each wall leading to the open kitchen.

The Beef Tendon appetizer ($7.50) came in a small plate that was overcooked with little texture. Portion size was underwhelming, and pieces were too small to pick up. Way overpriced. Do not order this dish. I was surprised the restaurant had the audacity to serve it.

The Chao Huyet Congee ($4.50) came with congealed pork blood and rice porridge. There was a decent amount of pork blood, but the consistencies of the porridge was not the creamiest or tastiest. It was overall comforting, but better versions are out there around the City. 

For the dried noodles, the server initially recommended the Wonton Noodles ($5.25), but brought us Dumpling Noodles (same price) instead. This dish came with three dumplings, egg noodles served dry, veggies, and clear broth on the side. The pork dumplings tasted decent but really lacking. The noodles were overcooked, leaving the diluted broth to be the only highlight.

The Wonton Noodle Soup ($5.25) came with five wontons, egg noodles, veggies, and clear broth. Two more dumplings than the previous dish was the major reason we enjoyed it better, which is not saying much.

The highlight of the night turned out to be the Chicken Rice Plate ($6.15/off menu). There was plenty of chicken in the stir-fry. The chicken was tender and delicious in the light brown sauce. 

It was overall an affordable meal, but we also got what we paid for. Interested diners should be aware of their cash only policy--and their unethical business practices. This led us to learn about their bottom line when the owner refused to provide us a receipt for the dinner (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yin-du-wonton-noodle-san-francisco?select=1BZTtWWL6zvo-1gd2biU4A&reviewid=TT3f57QbJTO3Qsx_EyZRnA). He insisted this is common practice in Chinatown, and generating receipts would create problems for him with the IRS. 

In turn, I then suggested to Santi to forgo tipping the restaurant, which prompted the restaurant owner to point his finger at the table, raised his voice, and demanded that we tip him. Once we refused again, he made the same gesture again, slam his palm at our table, and started yelling at us.

In hindsight, the restaurant owner essentially tried to nickle and dimed us with cheap ingredients, then tried to game the system at our expense, and then expected us to tip after we had been disrespected. I initially thought about tipping him for the theatrical outburst, but based on the food and treatment we should have received compensation for our suffering. We left the restaurant still hungry. 

To be fair to the other restaurants in Chinatown, I have never experienced anything like this in many years of living in the Bay Area. Those visiting the City should consider the restaurants in the Richmond and Sunset neighborhoods. This was one of the worst treatments I have ever encountered. We will not be coming back.
author: Daniel L.

description:
I came here on a weekday around 1pm and luckily, did not have to wait for a table of 3. I ordered the beef brisket and wonton noodle soup and we shared the beef tripe and the curry fish balls. The noodle soup was pretty good, but nothing too special, not amazing enough for me to go out of my way to come here. The curry fish balls were pretty good as well, I would probably re order this. The beef tripe however, I would not order again - it tastes better at dim sum places. They basically just boiled it and added some soy sauce on it.. 

The Service and cleanliness was not so great either, but what do you expect? It is in Chinatown. When we came in, they were wiping down our table using gloves. But they also never took off the gloves while giving us our eating utensils, our bill, napkins  and food, so that was a little disturbing..
author: Bailey L.

description:
Bomb. Dot. Com.

Everything is good.  I mean everything.

Start with the wonton noodles.
Meander your way to the beef stew.
Then mosey onto the beef tripe.
Top it all off with their signature milk tea.

If you like order everything on the menu.  You will not regret it.

The staff is so nice and so humble.

Make sure you tip them extra.  They are just the greatest people ever.
author: Jackie K.

description:
For $4-5 for a bowl of noodles, you really can't complain!

This is by far my favorite place for beef brisket noodles. The beef brisket was super soft and tender and it made the soup super flavorful! I also ordered it with wontons and the wontons had huge pieces of shrimp and were very yummy! Overall, well worth!
author: Leilani Y.

description:
I would 5 star for the food, without a doubt the best wanton noodle and porridge in Chinatown.  Got to try the pork liver porridge it's so smooth and it's not over cooked.

The service as expected is much to be desired.  Just sit and enjoy the food and you will be fine.  Once you are done, just go next door to have pastries and tea/coffee at New Hollywood Bakery & Restaurant.
author: A F.

description: The broth is so so delicious! Love the spicy chili sauce at the table. We ordered #2, wonton soup with shrimp/pork. Complimentary tea when you sit down. Cash only!!
author: Ashley C.

description: This hole in the wall place serves up some affordable noodles and rice plates. CASH ONLY though. Make sure that you order their beef or their wonton soup noodle. It is the absolute comfort food. Each meal is around $6-7. Definitely cheap eats in Chinatown.
author: Charlene F.

description:
Dingey hole in the way place but this is Chinatown, what do you expect! 

For what it is, the noodle soups are delicious, warming, and well cooked. Don't expect great service nor white glove table service. Come here for the yummy brothy soups and leave perfectly satisfied. Very inexpensive as well.
author: David J.

description:
Didn't want to share this with Yelp.  They are good and cheap!!!!  

Noodles texture is just perfect!
author: Deb L.

description:
If you're a light eater, this is a good place to come for a weekday lunch if you can actually get a seat. In most cases, you'll probably have to share a table with another group if you have 2 or less people around lunchtime.
Supposedly their noodles are msg free, and I would probably agree as their normal broth doesn't really have much flavor. This may or may not be a good thing, depends on your tastes.
If you want a broth with more flavor, get the beef brisket noodle soup. The beef marinate gives extra flavor to the broth. I believe this is their signature dish.
However, if you're a duck fan like me, you can get the duck wonton noodle soup. I always choose to get the fun noodles (flat rice noodles), and add extra noodles for $1.00. Total only comes out to be about $7.00 per person, throw in a few bucks for tip. 
Like most noodles dishes, even after stuffing myself during lunch, I'll be hungry again by 5 o'clock.

It's cash only here, and I usually have to have my friend order for me in Chinese, otherwise I'm not sure if my order will go through.
author: Mike O.

description: We stumbled onto this place after the restaurant next door (new regent)  had a bit of a wait.  Like most Chinese places in Chinatown, they share and split tables here so be warned if you're not used to this.  Ie like a couple may be sitting with a single person at the same table. Anyways their menu is pretty simple.  The same things just in different combinations with each other. Wontons,  two types of noodles,  soup,  beef brisket. So we ordered a wonton noodle and a beef brisket wonton noodle. And what came out was not whay I ordered.  Thus the 3 stars.   The wait staff is pretty informal so they didn't write down our order. Not wanting to offend them I decided not to fight it and just enjoy it. It was the beef brisket noodle soup.  The beef was tasty and there was a generous amount of it. Good split between between fatty and tendon pieces and straight up beef. I did get to try one of my friend's wontons. Pretty good. Also noodles were nicely cooked and al dente. And the soup was hot and had gpod flavor. They also brought put two cups of tea for us. If you want anything else, just have to ask.  The best part was its so cheap. 5 to 6 bucks for a good bowl of noodle soup. Cash only though. It filled me up pretty well but I could see aome guys being still hungry afterwards. Haha. Will be back wheb the cravings hit.
author: Alison W.

description: We came here for the Wonton Noodle soup. Ive been eating BBQ pork Wonton Noodle Soup for about 30 years. Its my favorite soup and am very passionate about finding a good bowl. Im a native of Chicago and its difficult to find a good spot other than the place Ive been going to for about 15 years. Din Wu is fantastic bowls of Wonton Soup. The service kinda sucks and not very friendly but thats what I expected at an authentic Chinese restaurant. None of that matters to me though. I'm just looking for a good bowl. Very tasty wonton and the noodles are perfectly cooked. I ordered the Duck Wonton Noodle Soup with extra noodles and its the first time ive ordered duck in the soup. I normally get the BBQ pork but they ran out. Just before I finished my bowl I ordered another bowl. The soup was only like $5.75 so you know its not a touristy type of place and for the locals. I'll be back.
author: Brandon E.

description: This is a small place that seem to be full by lunch time.  It serves affordable wonton and beef stew noodles.  It seem to have an older crowd.  The bowl is bigger than some in HK but smaller than compatible places in US.  Prepare to share a table for smaller groups.  The food was good but did not wow, however it's value is above average.
author: Tony C.

description:
All time must stops when in Chinatown.  Mom loved the beef brisket rice noodle soup.  It was one of her favorite last meals.
It's just a little hole in the wall run by a hardworking husband and wife team - not fancy but they make some of the bestChinese  beef brisket in town.
author: Jean Y.

description: Authentic Chinese taste with reasonable price, strongly recommended. The portion is big and the beef stew is a must try dishes.
author: Ken K.

description:
It was very bizarre.

When it comes to cravings, I normally crave flavors like chocolate, peanut butter, chocolate, jam, chocolate, coffee, chocolate, chocolate, chocolate. Sometimes I throw in some savory risk factors, like burgers and cheese, to round out my comorbidity spectrum. But never have I ever had such a sudden, intense craving for wontons as I did a few months ago. And by intense, I mean thought-consuming.

wontonwontonwontonwontonwonton
wontonwontonwontonwontonwonton
chocolatewontonwontonwontonwonton
wontonwontonwontonwontonwonton
wontonwontonwontonwontonwonton

Geez, I wish I could channel that relentless attention toward studying.

I ordered #9, the roast duck wonton noodle soup, for $5.25, + $1 for extra noodles. The broth was comforting, the duck was chewy, and the wontons, though nowhere near the best, did the trick. Thumbs up to the thin wrappers.

Now, back to normalcy.

chocolatechocolatechocolatechocolate
chocolatechocolatechocolatechocolate
chocolatechocolatechocolatechocolate
chocolatechocolatechocolatechocolate
chocolatechocolatechocolatechocolate
author: Adele F.

description:
Incredible price for value! I like the broth and veggies at Yin Du more than at Hons, but I have a slight preference for Hons more al dente noodles. 

Overall good spot that is about equal with Hons. Don't expect any customer service (at either venue) and prepare to share a table. 

They offer several sides which are as expensive as the bowls of soup. The tripe was very oily and the sauce was not good. 

Pro-tip: cash only.
author: Jess C.

description: The bill is thirteen dollars. I gave twenty dollars. On the other hand, it was only given fifteen. I won't come back to this restaurant again. Goodbye.
author: Miao L.

description:
You know this is a good deal when its over run with old Chinese ladies happily chowing away at their food.

First, this place is inexpensive.
Second, quick service.
Third, food is good if you know what to order.  (Hint, just take a look at what the old Chinese ladies are eating...)

Only downside is lack of seating.  It's definitely sit where there is a seat available kind of place.  That means you could be sitting at the same tables as those old Chinese ladies...like we did.

This was our least expensive meal in sf.  And we enjoyed it quite a bit.  Try the beef tendon dish.  The old Chinese ladies were having that at our table.
author: Lan C.

description: I mean quick service, free hot tea and a noodle soup for $5. You can't beat these prices anywhere! Noodle soup is bomb too!
author: Anjoleen S.

description: There was a bug floating in my soup. Used to love going to this place at least once a week. Was disappointed today.
author: Bonie M.

description:
Food was good, but I'm probably never coming back because of how stressful it was just to get a seat and order food. The servers expect you to know what you want as soon as you sit and also they will move you around even after you sit if it's more convenient for them to seat more people.

We got a side of galong veggie, wonton noodle soup, and beef stew noodle soup. The beef stew was the best.

Cash only and be prepared to share tables. I probably won't be back.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Good stuff!! Liked both their fun noodles and egg noodles. No MSG added, so my mom and I felt pretty good afterwards. The wontons were modest but flavorful. Love that it tasted like real ingredients, not a little bit of meat held together by a bunch of corn starch. At $5ish a bowl, totally a steal. Great place to stop by for snacks, in case you're eating your way through Chinatown!

(be prepared to be ignored, the service is trying. just wave them down hard and they're actually pretty efficient!)
author: Maggie G.

description:
If you want some traditional HK wonton noodles, this is the spot! Noodles are perfect and wontons are great. Plus it's only 5$! Everything on their menu is less than 10$. Congee is also delicious, very flavorful! 

Have been looking for some delicious and affordable places and this is prbly one the first in sf. Servers don't speak English super well, but they're super nice! Will def be coming back.
author: Doreen C.

description: Decent place for dinner. Wontons were the right size and taste with the soup not being overly salty. The curry fishballs were lacking though, had better quality ones before.
author: Stacy L.

description:
4 stars for the food. Very yummy! One of the better places in Chinatown. I'm definitely a fan. Great prices. Amazing wonton and brisket. I recommend the stewed beef brisket and wonton noodle soup (#4). The brisket is very soft and the broth has a lot of flavor. 

One star off for the service though. The places seems a little disorganized though. They never gave my friend the milk tea he ordered and I'm pretty sure they charged us for it :/ We couldn't tell though because they never gave us an itemized receipt and we were too tired to ask them about it (given the language barrier). 

Great food, but make sure they give you what you actually ordered lol
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Overall: 4/5
Great place for cheap, filling, tasty food. It's very affordable, the food is good, and I'd return.

Price: 5/5
AMAZING. An order is under $7 (most options are around $5).

Food: 4/5
Good HK style food. They have noodle soups, dumplings/wonton in soup, dry noodles, and some other dishes. I had the wonton noodle soup and the quality is good.

Service: 3/5 - 4/5
Service is barebones, which is fine. You come here for good food at great prices, not formal service. 
Note: The staff kept speaking Chinese to me, although I always replied back in English (sorry, it's a habit for mine... I'm very patriotic as a Chinese, but I'm more comfortable speaking English than broken Chinese). For those who don't understand Chinese, I assume they'll speak English to you.

Hours: 3/5
Closes early at 7pm... be warned if you're trying to go late at night :P
author: Nelson L.

description: If you like typical Chinese food, this place is perfect. The place is not really clean but the food is good. The price was the best part
author: Almudena V.

description:
Thought this place was mediocre. The restaurant staffed no one that spoke English. Luckily I knew a few words of Chinese and was able to order. We had the fish ball curry, wonton, and porridge. 

The fish ball curry tasted like just the frozen fish balls you can get at Asian markets sautéed in curry sauce. 

The wonton soup and porridge was average in my opinion. Maybe they're known for something else but I don't believe it's these items we ordered.
author: Eric D.

description:
This is a small HK style wonton noodle place, serving pretty good wonton noodle soup. The noodles are quite a bit better than average and wontons are small but tasty. I usually get the beef stew wonton noodle soup, the beef stew is nice and chewy but not too tough, with just the right amount of gristle.  Strangely, they don't have an option for extra wonton - you only get about 5 or 6 per bowl, so when I'm hungry, I like to order a side of beef tendon. The tendons have the same sauce as the beef stew, so it compliments the beef stew wonton perfectly. 

As typical for this type of establishment, service is very fast and efficient.  The menu has a "no MSG" symbol on it, but I'm not sure if that's accurate. Overall, I think it's a bit better than Hon's Wun Tun House on Kearny around the corner.
author: Allen T.

description: I was in the area from out of town and I was super craving some duck noodle soup so I yelped "duck noodles" and sure enough this spot came up.. Theres only a few tables inside so we had to share a table even though we only had a party of 2. They serve fast and the food is decent. The egg noodles were al dente.. which were perfect but the only thing I can complain about is the duck.. There wasn't much meat but I guess its just for the flavor??
author: Rainbow W.

description:
Noodle, wonton and vegetable ratio is perfect. 

Their duck and beef brisket wonton noodle soups are super good! 

Yin Du Wonton Noodle is not open on Wednesday!

Cash only spot!
author: Alice X.

description:
Stopped by in our visit to San Francisco. Granted, with little experience of dining in China Town, I'm not really able to benchmark this little place with other restaurants close by , but the food is seriously good.  I was NOT expecting to have any authentic Hong Kong style Won Ton Noodle with a price tag of $5 in San Francisco ( coz the lunches in Financial District can easily go above $ 15).  We ordered beef tender rice noodle soup and wonton noodle soup, and both are pretty authentic as you walked in a small place in Hong Kong for breakfast/brunch, with Cantonese surrounding customers.  

I give 5 stars for food, 1 star deduction for service but 1 star added back for the super affordable price tag.
author: Jingwen X.

description: I really needed porridge for my boyfriend since he had a cold. I called up this place and they made 2 orders to go. My boyfriend had chicken with green onions and mine was plain (I went home and added my own ingredients-- Hong Kong style jook). All in all it gets the job done on a rainy cold day and you don't want something super savory like soup or Ramen. When I went in to pick up my order they were wrapping fresh dumplings so I should go back and try that as it seems as though they make it from scratch.
author: Yvonne L.

description:
DELICIOUS and authentic Hole in the wall place with hole in the wall prices ($5-7.25 dishes!). This place was great with fast service, but as always the people running the place didn't speak English. Best to figure what you want and point at the menu to order. 

The wonton beef soup was amazing!
author: Tommy D.

description:
Yes yes yes finally, another place in Chinatown that I actually like. While their offerings remind me, in a way, of a severely limited version of Hai Ky Mi Gia's menu, I suppose their dishes are actually fairly different. Okay, ignore that comparison.

Anyway, coming with a few coworkers, I ended up ordering their roast duck wonton noodle soup. And while the amount of duck that was in that bowl was kind of pitiful, I really wasn't expecting much for $5. In fact, at $5, I was more than pleased: the bowls may be on the small side for most, but were actually perfectly portioned for my appetite. Logistics aside, the food itself tasted fantastic: the broth had excellent flavor, the noodles were nice and springy, and the wontons were also quite tasty.

Definitely hitting up this place more, especially since the new office is right in this area!

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A decently sized space, with tables positioned in such a way that only the ones at the ends are easily accessible. Don't go during busy hours, and you should be fine.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out.
author: Johnny W.

description: We have driven from so cal up to Whidbey Island over the last 12 days and have found Asian cuisine at every place we stayed. Yin Du is definitely our favorite restaurant we found through Yelp. Our kids, ages 4 and 7, shared  and finished a bowl of egg noodle soup. My husband had the pork and shrimp wonton soup with noodles. He is really picky about broth and he mentioned how "clean" the broth was about a dozen times. I had the beef brisket with wonton and noodles. Holy cow, amazing. My family wanted to try the brisket in my soup and we all agreed that it was incredibly tasty and tender. I normally don't like tripe, but I tried it here and I really liked it. Very mild but flavorful and the texture was unlike other tripe I've tried at other restaurants.  This will be on our list of must eats when we return to San Francisco.
author: Elisa A.

description: Cheap and quick place to grab a bite to eat. Ordered the Beef stew dry noodle and curry fish balls. Portions are decent. They seat you where ever there's an empty seat which is cool. No need to wait lol.
author: Philip L.

description: Refreshingly cheap, in this ridiculously expensive city. Was feeling sick and needed a big bowl of wanton soup, so stopped here on my way home. Delicious and comforting.
author: Paula I.

description:
I ordered a beef stew Togo. When I go pick it up. Total was 8.50 with tax. The portion was unbelievable small. A lady next to me was also picking up her to go said "wth this is so small, are you going to be full?"

I looked at the owner and said "seriosuly this small portion"? He says "Yes eveyone gets this size". 

Didn't want to be an ass hole so I took it anyway. 

Noodle taste blant. Soup is salty. Not enough meat. 1 string of vege.....
author: Jerome J.

description: I think I need to stop eating here for awhile. There was a little fly in my beef stew wonton noodle soup today and I've been getting diarrhea since and hopefully it goes away soon. In the past, there were small roaches and a few days ago a pretty long string inside one of my wonton. I remembered one time they dropped a vegetable on the floor but instead of throwing it away. They placed it into the customer's order and I felt that isn't right. Actually, it's whether scary!
author: May W.

description: Delicious, satisfying, classic, cheap and fresh rice noodles.
author: Lily H.

description:
It's cash only but you'll only need a few dollars. Save the money you'd use for coffee and a muffin to come here instead. The wonton noodle soup with duck is really good. Clean and clear broth with tender pieces of roasted duck and wontons swimming in egg noodles. 

Also get the chinese broccoli with oyster sauce on the side. They steam it fresh for you and it comes out tender but with a good bite to it. The place is relatively new too so it's plenty sanitary (I hope). Much like other asian restaurants - this place is like a factory, you get in, get served, eat, pay and leave. All in 30 minutes unless you like to take pictures like us.
author: Quoc N.

description:
Fairly new wonton place near the grandparents house.

For the price and how delicious the beef brisket wonton soup noodle, you can't beat it anywhere else. Beef brisket was very flavorful and melted in your mouth. Broth was good as well. A definite must try.

Curry Fish Balls - Not bad, but quite average and I wouldn't get it again. 

If there's a wait, there's not waitlist, it's he said/she said who came first and waited. 

Definitely would come back again when I'mm at CT and craving wonton.
author: Harriet W.

description:
Food and price would be around 3 stars, but service is a definite 1 star, and this is already baselined with Chinatown service standards, where you generally expect the staff to have a no frills approach. My friend and I ordered two bowls of noodles for around $11 (seriously can't complain about the prices), and we noticed that when the bill came they added in an extra $1.50. We assumed that was tip, since some places in Chinatown will bake in tip without telling you (which really makes me want to tip them even less). When we got up to leave, the waitress rushed over and tapped on the table, demanding that we leave an additional tip. When I asked her about the extra $1.50, at first she pretended to not understand me, then loudly told me it for the tea, which they had placed in front of without even asking if we wanted it. Not wanting to cause a scene over a few dollars, we gave her "tip" and left. After reading other Yelp reviews, it seems like the hot tea is supposed to be complimentary and the server lied to us. Overall the experience was extremely uncomfortable and I felt taken advantage of... and if the noodles were good enough to justify the rudeness, I would come back, but really they were only meh at best.

Overall sad noodles, sad experience, sad times all around :(
author: Hali M.

description: CASH ONLY. Cheap Chinese food. I don't remember the last time I saw single digit prices for everything on the menu (never in SF). Pretty good food too. I got #4 and I really liked the pork in the noodle soup! Definitely coming back and getting pork entrees next time.
author: Annie S.

description:
First time here.  The beef stew was awesome.  Tender and flavorful.  They also do not add MSG.  Wanton noodles were not bad although my wife felt they could have added more shrimp.  Overall, food was tasty and not overly salty.

I got a kick out of the "bad" reviews.  Most had to do with waiting, the sharing of tables, noise and sometimes "rude", auntie waitresses.  These are typical Hong Kong, "hole in the wall" restaurants experiences.  An authentic experience.  If this is not your thing, don't come.
author: George F.

description:
Well, ordered BBQ pork/Wonton noodles, plain dumpling soup, and beef brisket/wonton noodles, ALL were very disappointing!

First of all, the broth appears to be just hot water. BBQ pork was tasteless and beef brisket was without the traditional flavor. Wonton and dumplings are no better than the frozen ones I can get from the market. Even the noodles are subpar. 

Service? What service! All the ladies wore gloves, but it is the SAME pair of gloves for removing dirty dishes, wiping down the table, collecting money, violating your "clean" chop sticks/spoons, and deliver your tea by HOLDING ON TO YOUR TEA CUP BY THE RIM IN 360 Degrees! I kept an eye at the bathroom...

I guess I expected too much from the 4 Star rating average. I am just disappointed but not socked. Grew up in Hong Kong, I am not easily shocked. Won't go back even if they pay me.
author: Don S.

description:
I came here to grab a quick lunch with my dad. 

This restaurant has only been open for about a year or so, but business is booming there were plenty of people waiting in line, and they had a really high turnover rate in tables.  We waited for about 15 minutes and were finally seated. 

They are known for their ngau nam mien here ( stewed beef brisket soup), but I wanted to try their pig feet soup, so I ordered that instead.  We also ordered the ngau nam fan ho soup and the gai lan with oyster sauce. 

The noodles came out pretty quickly, in less than 5 min., and they were hot and fresh.  The pig feet was super tender, soft, and tasty.  The noodles were very chewy and not too soft at all.  The reason why I am giving them 4 stars is because they are not the cleanest restaurant, ( my tea cup had a lipstick stain on it ), and they forgot about our gai lan, so that didn't come out until we reminded them about it.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
Super yummy porridge and wonton soup. Super great service. Love this place. They say it's got no MSG and I do think it's true. 

This place is wicked clean and sometimes you get seated next to complete strangers :) And strangers sometimes just sit down right next to you without the host saying anything, it's friggin awesome.
author: Alex C.

description: Cheap tasty ...   wasn't sure about this place first. A friend of mine had to use restroom and we happened to be on this street. Just went in and while he uses restroom, i ordered just on dish, wanton noodle soup.  Thinking that if now good, we will just go other places.  To our surprise, it was good. We ended up ordering 4 more. Good portion, tasty food, very cheap.  These make me forget about not so friendly service.  I mean they are not bad at all just it seems speaking English is not necessary at all.
author: M-K C.

description: This place was easy, no-fuss, cheap and most importantly, tasty! We ordered the wonton noodle soup for $5. Well worth it. Recommend if you're in the area looking for a quick bite.
author: Hannah W.

description:
Best beef noodle soup I've ever had!! It's kind of a hole in the wall and everyone shares tables due to it being small. But everyone is friendly.

Remember like most hole in the walls - it's cash only
author: Wendy T.

description:
Fairly small wonton shop, that specializes in making wonton noodles.

The size of the restaurant is fairly small, with a limited number of tables. The portions are also quite small as well, and the wontons are also very small in size, BUT, so is the price. For $4-$5 per bowl, it's great bang for the buck, and you can always get 2 bowls if you're feeling hungry (I only got one).

I got the cold lemon tea, which was very well made, with just the right amount of sweetness. It was served on a tall, simple cylinder glass, which was simple yet appropriate.

Along with the fact that this is one of the cleanest restaurants I know in Chinatown, this is definitely a decent place to sit down, relax, and enjoy quality food (if you can find a seat)
author: Henry L.

description:
Limited menu, but awesome wonton soup and rice congee.

It 's taken me over 2 years to get to Yin Du, because they are not open late. Yin Du close's at 8pm and I don't usually start thinking about food till well after 8:30pm. They are also cash only.

Their Wonton Soup is awesome! The wontons are shrimp and pork based and have just the right flavor and texture. I still prefer the wontons' at Hon's Wun Tun House, but Yin Du's are a close second.

The Wonton Duck noodle soup is also very good.  The duck comes the traditional way, thick slices with bone in. 

SIDEBAR: This cutting duck and chicken with the bone in is one chinese tradition I've never understood. Yes, I get it the bone bits contribute to the the flavor of the meat, but I just wonder how many tooth fractures could be avoided knowing that when you chew into a piece of meat that all the bone fragments had been removed ahead of time. 

Congee is pretty easy to cook, but Yin Du's is perfectly done.

I also liked their curried fish balls and chinese broccoli with oyster sauce. 

Yin Du's curry chicken, was just average.  Stick to the Wonton Soup and Congee, that's what they do really well.
author: David T.

description: Did you know won ton = 24,000 won ton?  I was happy to find this lil gem in the wall, clean, updated decor, and the won tons!  Reminds me when I was a kid in Chinatown and eating at Golden Dragon noodooh house back in the day! That was the BEST ever. You have choice of mien or rice noodoohs, beef, duck, cha siu, and of course a couple pieces o veggie.  They have other assorted small plates too. And the price though! $5.25? Now that's a real deal Chinatown price.... And to add to authenticity, they speak toi sang, an old country dialect that reflects the first Chinese immigrants to San Francisco.
author: Cali C.

description: Love their beef stew noodle, even though it may not look as high end as other places the food is good and the workers are nice!:)
author: Annie W.

description: Was in Chinatown on a Sunday and Hon's was closed, so I decided to try a new place that was highly rated for won ton noodle.  I was sorely disappointed.  The won tons were mostly meat with the smallest single shrimp.  The noodles were soggy.  The soup was the usual msg broth.  Also tried their pei dan sau yook jook, and they did not salt it at all.  The pork slices were grisly and tough.  It was very disappointing.  Now I kinda know why my parents say there's nothing good to eat in Chinatown anymore.
author: Sammich C.

description: I wish I could give zero star for this restaurant. This place should close at seven, and it's only 6:35 and the guy asking us to leave by waving his hand in a very rude way without saying anything. The reason why I want to eat at this place because it's four stars on Yelp. I know it's not a fine dining place but I don't know how did they get four stars without respecting their customer.
author: Lyn Z.

description: Simple clean comfort food. We were craving a nice simple meal and this did the job. The wontons were prepared fresh and really tasty. The beef brisket stew was really delicious. Id pass on the curry fishballs nothing special.
author: Prima Z.

description:
My favorite place to get my wonton noodle soup craving when I'm out with family. Yeah you can make it at home but their beef stew and is constantly on point. I haven't been disappointed with food all the times that I've eaten here with family. Portions are decent. One bowl is good enough for me. When they're busy and short on tables expect them to seat you at a table with someone else. They might not even ask if you're ok with it but hey, I think it's worth it. You get food in yoir belly faster :) Service is mediocre. It's what is to be expected. Nothing exceptionally bad but nothing to boost about in my opinion. 

Overall worth it for lunch if you're in the area. Portions are decent and not pricy. Cash only!
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
Found this cafe via Yelp and was not disappointed. Pretty much everything was accurately described. 
I tried their #9 Roast Duck Wonton Noodle Soup (and I got THREE pieces of duck...score!). It was good.  The owner(?) recommended #33 Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce. I have to say this was the best part of my meal. This would make me come back and try more food at Yin Du if I had the time.
author: George S.

description:
Not sure how their food tastes as I didn't get a chance to try it.  Based on the experience of my first visit, I won't bother finding out about their food anyway. 

My parents and I were at SF last week for a family trip.  Based on the reviews, I picked this restaurant as our lunch place during the day when we visited Chinatown.    

It was raining so I dropped my parents in front of the entrance and watched them walking into, before driving away to find parking.  When I came back, I was very surprised as they were standing at the intersection not far from Yin Du and waiting for me, in the rain.

If you wondered what happened: the place was nearly empty when my parents walked in, they first sat down at a table that was set up with 4 sets of utensils, then a guy (potentially the owner) working there asked them to move to a smaller table which had 2 sets of utensils on top.  My dad told the guy we actually had 3 and the other table might be too small.  The guy became really annoyed and started yelling really loudly that he will add another set.  Dad was shocked by his reaction and decided to leave.  Since they were not familiar with the neighborhood they stayed around to wait for me...

Maybe something significant will happen to the restaurant when a group of 3 sits at a table for 4,  hence the yelling and screaming?  Regardless, I can't let it slide when my parents were treated rudely, I believe nobody can, even that guy at the restaurant.
author: Jessica L.

description: I originally had 2 star in my mind, but the curry fish balls brought it up a notch. They use better quality fish balls than most places. Other than that is is a super home style Chinese noodle shop / diner. Don't expect crazy good service or ambiance. The food is ok. I had the wonton beef stew noodle soup as well. The menu says they close at 630pm everyday and it's cash only.
author: Wesley M.

description: This place is at the perfect intersection of taste (good but not fabulous ), ambience  (steps above divey, but not necessarily in a higher class) and price (just outright cheap!).  Heck half the times when I have walked in here in the evenings, the ladies are sitting in the dining room with a giant mound of patty pork and making wontons right there!.  This is not going to win any awards, but are pretty good eats. Simple clean broths, nice chewy noodles and porky and shrimpy wontons grace the bowl with a nice garnish of chinese broccoli adding a touch of green to the presentation.  All I know is that everytime I have been there, i have pigged out and still left with money in my pocket and there is a lot to be said about that!
author: Sunay P.

description:
Wow. What a night! Came here today for the first time with my family around 6pm, luckily there was 1 table open and we sit down. They were very busy since there were two large parties that were there before us, we still got our food in a timely manner.

Service was to the point, and friendly. We ordered beef tendon hor fun (but they sold out and we got normal noodles instead); dumpling and noodle soup, a side of plain wontons; curried fish balls; and an iced lemon sweet tea.

Taste: everything was good, the beef tendon was super tasty! Portions on the noodles were pretty good. Compared to some food tho (like large pho) this may seem small. I still left pretty full and got an egg custard tart nearby for dessert. 

Cost: super affordable!


Side story: 
As we were finishing up our dinner, this mandarin speaking family walked into the restaurant. The waiter tells them they are closed. Now this was before 7pm, which is their closing time, but they ran out of food so they refused service to this family.
Here's the crazy part: this family barged in anyway, this lady lead her kids to the back of the restaurant to use their bathroom (seems like without asking), and when another server asks them to leave, they started shouting at the workers, saying things like "how can you do business like this" and "I'm going to report you to the police". (Here I'm thinking wtf lady, they ran out of food, just leave). 
What's worse is then the older man with this family shoved the waitress! The waiter (presumably the owner) tries to calm the guy down, with his hands held up to hold the guy away from the waitress. From outside another guy walks in, started loudly telling them not to touch his dad, while his lady companion shouts like a crazy person on about assault and calling the police, and writing online about how terrible of a business they were, etc. 
This whole thing came to an end when the waiter started bowing and saying I'm sorry profusely until that rude family left. 
Man, we felt so bad for the people working there, and waited a while before leaving, in case they do call the police on them. 
And I'm writing this really long review in case they write some bs later here.
author: DT Y.

description: Nice quick and delicious. This is the place that Chinese go. Very nice we enjoyed our food very much
author: Naghmeh T.

description: Need a bowl of warm won ton noodles to warm your tummy? Yin Du Won Ton Noodle is for you :) This is a small and authentic Chinese Won Ton Noodle place? Did I mention that it is inexpensive?
author: Fanny T.

description: Reasonable prices. Tried beef stew twice it was well done but the authentic taste just wasn't there.....way too sweet.....lacking anise/peppercorns. Watch out: my takeout pig's feet was 95% bones. Service was grumpy but not surprised.
author: V L.

description: The broth is clear and flavorful. The favor is the beef stew. My son likes the beef stew with thin rice noodles (my fun). It's a great choice for a cold day.
author: Wayne L.

description:
OHEMGEE. So good. One of the best meals during our short stay in SF. And it only cost us $11. For two people. Including tip. What what?!

Preserved Egg & Pork Congee
Flavorful. Good consistency. I just prefer my preserved eggs to be cut up into smaller pieces. I love congee!

Stewed Beef Brisket & Rice Noodle Soup
Decided on this over the wonton noodle soup since we like rice noodles better. I make really good decisions. 'Cause the noodles were delicious, the beef brisket was tender, and the broth was super flavorful without making me feel greasy and unhealthy. Good ratio of ingredients.

Setting was brighter and cleaner than I expected. Just a bit drafty. But girl, oh girl, do I still daydream about this meal.

CASH ONLY!
GO GO GO!
author: San W.

description: Went in today and tried to order a bowl of beef brisket wonton noodle soup to share between three people, and the owner yelled at us in Chinese for costing him business by taking up a table of four and just ordering one item. WTF. We were not impressed, and we left without trying the food.
author: Jennie T.

description:
Food is ok. 

Waiting time is kinda long. 

Waiter sat down next to us while taking orders, which I'm perfectly fine with. 

But when the check came, waiter asked for tip twice as if I won't pay tips at all while eating a banana (mouth full)...
author: Stephen C.

description:
Still the best! I introduced this place to my family this time after browsing around the Chinese New Year festival. No wait for the six of us! That is a major perk during this time of festivities where you would be waiting almost 15-20 mins elsewhere. The main compliment I heard from the family was that the noodles and gai-lan were cooked perfectly with a nice crisp.

I believe the prices have went up slightly but nothing more than a quarter. Still the only place at which I would eat wonton noodle soup.

Tip: Cash only!
author: Henry P.

description:
Overall average at best. One of the better places in Chinatown but, really, none of the food in Chinatown is very good. You're better off going 30mins out of the city if you have the time.

But if you're walking in the city and find yourself in Chinatown, this place is ok. Place is small with just a few tables, might be a short wait. Cash only and moves quickly. Got the won ton noodles and the size was small, you'll need to order other items as well most likely.

The soup flavor was good but the noodles and meat weren't that great. There was a roach going across the floor too.
author: Joey L.

description:
This place was ok. I have to say I really like the wonton noodles but didn't really enjoy the wontons so much. I may be more used to the wontons with more shrimp versus pork. The wonton was a little hard compared to others and I just didn't enjoy it that much. I really liked the noodles though. If they could combine ABC cafe's wontons and Yin Du's noodles...that'd be awesome. 

Milk tea was surprisingly good. Maybe because I wasn't expecting much? Lemon honey drink was ok, it tasted more like lemon honey tea. 

The service there was ok. The lady who took our order kept missing things we were telling her and one of the orders came out wrong. But the place was pretty clean and overall it was ok. 

I'd go back if it was close by but I probably wouldn't go out of my way to get there.
author: Kelly Y.

description:
******I would rate this negative if it were an option******
******I first thought they were rude, but now I think they were more HOSTILE*****

This has made it to the top of the bad service list. This says a lot given my expectation for Chinese restaurants is already very low. 

We were waiting in line on a Sunday around 1pm and three tables freed up. The folks in line were

1) a party of 2
2) me + 1
3) party of 3
4) party of 3 

They seated the first party of 2 and demanded that we shared the same table that was made for 4, but with very very tight space so the meal would be extremely uncomfortable. We offered to wait. 

They seated the party of 3 comfortably. Then the third open table was a table for 2.  I requested to sit there since, although it was still sharing with another couple, it was a bit more spacious. Then as we sat, they hushed us up and said they won't serve us if we sat there. Instead, they told the party of 3 to take the table.  They were not happy either but seeing what happened to us, they just took the offer. 

So we were FORCED to share a table. We were not given menus,and each waitress, along with the owner, said extremely rude and unfriendly stuff as they walked by us:

1) Don't eat here. We don't need your business 
2) you have to sit here
3) just leave

Worried that they might spit or do other disgusting things to our food after this hostile encounter, we got up and left. 

I'm always the table sharing type (love to share at Z&Y) but the space was extremely uncomfortable.  

I'm not sure why they felt it was ok to be so rude to their customers, but I would warn everyone I know to never ever visit this place.
author: Emily W.

description: At first the wonton soup was really flavourful but near the end it tasted a bit sour. The shrimp wonton fillings didn't have a recognizable texture and did not have much flavour. Overall, I was quite disappointed with the wontons considering that this is a wonton place.
author: James S.

description: Food just fine, they only accept cash and waitress is very rude, she force us to give 20% of our total bill as tips, won't recommend to my friends and won't go back again
author: Stella W.

description:
Small shop located near the edge of Chinatown. I actually been here a couple of times and this is a great family owned restaurant for a quick and cheap lunch! 

The menu itself consists of Wonton noodle soups, some rice places, and congee. I only tried the wonton noodle soups here so my review is based solely on that.

Each bowl of wonton noodle soup is around $5. You can pick between the toppings you want (wontons, beef stew, roast duck... etc) It comes with one strand of choy (vegetable) Serving is relatively small, but what do you expect, it's $5. 

One thing to mention is that the menu states that this is a MSG-free place. However, they do not make their own broth. If you look inside the kitchen, you can see Chinese chicken soup powder-- not exactly the same as MSG but it does the same job-- additional flavoring.

Lastly, like most Chinese restaurant, it isn't the cleanest place. I found a hair in my food before. However, this is for sure still cleaner than most shops at Chinatown.
author: Jenny N.

description:
I came here two days in a row, first day I ordered wonton (shrimp&pork) noodle soup. After the first bite, I decided to order takeout food, the wonton soup and fish congee. 
I couldn't stop craving for the noodle, so I came back and ordered stewed beef brisket & noodle soup.
Everything was so good, the food and the service. They have the nice, clean and also air conditioning restaurant. 
I would highly recommend this place for noodle lovers.
author: Ivy L.

description:
Super good! Didn't want a ton of food and was looking for a value. I wasn't disappointed! No line, fast service, and most importantly... Delicious!!
Had the beef brisket with wontons and noodle soup, plus am extra side of bok choy with oyster sauce. Really hit the spot.
author: Jason G.

description:
We were so hungry the other day lol and I just randomly picked up this restaurant since the rating for this place on Yelp has been 4/5 stars lol I trusted most yelpers lol 

The food is pretty cheap. Really really cheap. But I don't think the ingredients are fresh. My stomach didn't feel so well after that meal lol
author: Alanda B.

description:
Small space but very affordable.

Price ranges from $4-$6 for the wonton soups. Food prep was VERY slow during lunch. I had the duck wonton. In the bowl was 4 wontons and 3 small pieces of duck. Duck was delicious but there was very little meat and the pieces were very small. Broth and noodles were just ok. For the low price, I would come back.
author: Benita M.

description: Five bucks well spent. It's standard good wonton soup - nothing exceptional but it's a reasonably priced lunch and great on a cold gloomy day. However,  I could've skipped the cold milk tea -- it was not worth the extra beverage splurge. We came around 1:30 pm so there were still a good amount of people but a nice cozy spot available for Moe M. and me to catch up over some steaming bowls.
author: Natasha P.

description: Yin Du is my go to place when I'm looking for good, cheap wonton soup. If you come here during lunch, it's a bit difficult to find a seat due to how popular the place is. Service here is blazing fast. Once you order, it's literally a 5 minute wait for your food to come. Portions here are filling enough that you'll leave satisfied. If you're sensitive to sodium, don't drink all the broth from the soup as it's definitely on the salty side.
author: Austin W.

description: A great gem in SF Chinatown which has a lot of misses. The prices are super reasonable (cash only). Get the beef brisket stew in any variation. Guaranteed deliciousness. It's a small place, and during peak hours be prepared to wait outside. The service isn't great, but you're not going or paying for service. Just have that in your mind.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
I had their wonton and beef brisket noodle soup.

Delicious and authentic wontons should have more shrimps than pork and with rich of flavors that just makes you hunger for even more wontons.
