Here in this place, the wontons were tasteless with hard pork and less shrimps. The beef brisket was so stingy so I couldn't judge the taste and flavors from the tiny amount I got. 

I left the place hungry.. and just wanted to look for another place for food.
author: Michael N.

description:
Baby you're my everything, you're all I ever wanted...You da freakin best you da freakin best
You the da best I ever had....best I ever had...

You know, sometimes Drake just gets me. He knows EXACTLY how I feel as I slurp down my bowl of Yin Du's ngou lam fun, (that's beef brisket with rice noodles in Cantonese). The meat falls apart from hours of stewing. The tendon is soft and melts in your mouth. The broth is thick with flavor. In short, the best I ever had.

Honestly, my wallet's probably singing along too, as I shell out a mere five and some cents (pre-tip) for my brief trip to tastebud happiness. 

Lastly, here's my two cents, Yin Du Wonton Noodle should really be called Yin Du Ngo Lam Fun Noodle. Not to diss the wontons, but the beef noodle stew is where it's at!
author: Tracey L.

description:
It's a slight trek from FiDi, but it's definitely worth it if you want a good deal. Legit wonton duck wonton noodle soup for $4.95. They give around three pieces of juicy duck with the noodle soup, and it's cheaper than Hon's wonton noodle soup down the street, which increased their prices to $5.25 for a bowl now.

They also have a larger variety of dishes than Hon's wonton, such as porridge, rice plates, and milk tea. Of course, don't expect to pay with credit card at these prices. Also, you just need to wave your had a bit to catch the attention of the wait staff, but they're very responsive. 

Yin Du definitely makes my lunch rotation list.
author: Audrey L.

description:
This was pretty disappointing for a restaurant serving a  limited range of Cantonese staples. 

Noodles were overcooked (both the soup as well as the dry noodles) as were the vegetables (Gai Lan). The wontons fillings weren't high quality (low shrimp to pork ratio), and the wonton soup just tasted like salt water. 

The only saving grace was the stewed beef which was half-decent and a cold honey lemon drink.
author: Viv C.

description:
If you're a believer in value, then you're a believer of Yin Du. I feel like I've WON a TON with this kind of deal. (Slaps knees, pats back, hair flip)

There's a handful of quaint homelike shops like this one, so what it boils down to is 50% rating for the food and 50% rating for the cute little ladies that work here.

Yin Du's wontons, beef stew, and noodle soups are a solid 3.5/5, and could be much better if its broth had more depth/less bouillon.

It's true charm is still its staff, 5/5. They're just so sweet and seem like the best of friends. Makes me feel pretty happy just being in that kind of environment.

However, shoutout to Hon Wun Tun Noodle House a few blocks down that has incredibly delicious wontons and wider variety of dishes for about the same price. Staff there is a cute elderly couple....so depending on my mood, I'd go to either shop.
author: Vi T.

description:
I may have found my wonton place...I stumbled upon this place because I really wanted to eat wonton noodles and my previous to-go place was closed on a Sunday. This place is surprisingly very clean, new and air conditioned. Situated in Chinatown, I knew that the restaurants are typically not known for cleanliness so I wasn't expecting too much. However, I walked in and realized the whole restaurant was very clean. How nice.

I ordered a number 2 on the menu which is the same as number 1 but with noodles. trust me on this one. Basically, its the wonton with noodles soup. Just go with it.

Taste: Fantastic. Very authentic. In addition, there wasn't anything too savory so I assume they didn't put in much MSG ( you can tell). Good standard portion of both wontons and noodles. Also a perfect ratio of the both so I wasn't just overwhelmed with noodles or wontons. 

Price: CHEAP. SO CHEAP. The bill came out for a bowl of fulfilling wonton noodle soup for $5.06. 

Verdict: I'm coming back here the next time I come to Chinatown to see my people.
author: Eileen W.

description:
Before you write me off as an ABC who doesn't know what she's talking about, let me clarify that my parents are from Hong Kong, I have been there back and forth even even before I was old enough to walk, and as of recently have been to a Michelin starred wonton restaurant in Hong Kong. I am a foodie. I know my wontons. 

That being said, I was super excited to see that Yin Du was open late after their posted hours due to the Chinese New Year Parade. I plopped down and ordered my wonton noodle soup. At a first glance, the wontons are small...but for $5 what do you expect? The noodles were good, they were bouncy and not soggy or sticking together in clumps. The wontons though, were a bit disappointing. Of the 6 "shrimp and pork" wontons in my bowl, 2 had shrimp in them. The other four were stuffed with maybe 3/4 tablespoons of pork. The ground pork was not flavored well. It still had that pork "smell" in the wonton. Also, because the wontons were small, you could taste and see all folds they had to make to keep the dumpling together. For $5, I'm not going to complain, but I'm also not going to rely on this place to fulfill my wonton cravings.
author: Michelle C.

description:
My wife took me here one Saturday because she told me it was a very good wonton noddle shop. But again is just sad that this is an imitation of Hon's on Kearny st. Well maybe one of the cook from Hon's open this thinking they know what they are doing. There operation and procedures and serving size is almost like Hon's. But the big big differences is they are cheap and not taste as good well I should put it this way not eatable. 

1. They try to copy the soup base which they are too cheap would'nt spend that extra pennies to make a better soup base. Taste just like powder from instant noodls.

2.  They cooked the noodle 3 minutes too long taste mushy and still can smell some ammonia smell. big disappointment.

3. They try to cover it up with a cheaper price and just a little bite more on the portion.
This will only fool me 1 time but for sure it will fooled a lot of other chinese folks out there.

Overall experience not good very disappointed. If people would use their so call brain for a second and think about it we would not have all these so call Authentic chinese restaurant in business to serve people that just want to enjoy eatery.
author: Tommy M.

description:
This is a small, spartan joint right beside a certain other Chinese restaurant that's packing them in. But that's not the point. 

This place stands on it's own feet. 

Had beef and hand-pulled noodles and thought it was great. You can tell hand-pulled noodles are really good when they have a certain springiness to them when you bite them. And these were some damn springy noodles. 

The soup had good spice and the beef was fall apart tender. 

As it was a cold, extremely windy day, hot soup was a welcome meal. If I'm back in the city, I'll be sure to try out their other offerings.
author: Andrew C.

description:
On a rainy day I was on the hunt for some noodle soup and made the trek to Chinatown to try Yin Du =)

I walked in around noon and it wasn't too packed, but it's a small place to begin with. I was seated immediately and the lady brought me a piping hot cup of tea which I drank while reading the menu. I decided on the duck and wonton noodle soup, and five minutes later it was in front of me! 

The portion was actually pretty substantial; lots of noodles, 4 or 5 wontons, two pieces of what looked like gai lan, and three pieces of duck. I was a bit sad that the pieces of duck had a lot of bones, but the taste was awesome and the duck fat was delicious. I dropped some hot chili sauce on top of the noodles which really punched up the flavor, and the delicate soup broth was perfect on a rainy day. The prices here can't be beat, the food is good, and the service is fast!
author: Sam F.

description: Good quality food, very authentic to real china noodle shop... friendly service to Chinese and foreigners.... feels like I am back in Hong Kong dai pai dong.....
author: J N.

description:
I just like that it's clean (photo: http://bit.ly/19ykuEp). Is that a valid reason to come here? No, not by itself, not even for Chinatown where greasy spoons and overpacked bakeries stand next to ornate imperial palaces fit for emperors...or at least fit for Martin Yan. And after all, Yan can cook but can Yin Du? Well, if Yin can't Du, then Yin could teach...like Civics. I'm sure that's how my 4th grade gym teacher Coach Fiorello got his job, certainly not because of his bad crew-cut. But I digress. Yin can Du a decent won ton noodle soup, but it doesn't blow out my cylinders. It doesn't matter that much since I have so few cylinders left anyway. Jamie W. and I came here because I noticed it has been earning some pretty consistent praise, and a praiseworthy noodle house is something to cherish. Like everyone says, I think its nearest competitor is probably Hon's Wun Tun House on Kearny, which isn't as clean-looking and awfully orange.

But I did make up lyrics to the theme song I made up for Hon's, which needs "musical" accompaniment by the old guy who plays that two-string fiddle on Grant. Wanna sing along? (review:  http://bit.ly/165c7j9). Yin Du needs a theme song or something to spark some excitement to dawdle over to this quiet stretch of Pacific. Otherwise, it's a fairly humdrum menu that in the right mood, may hit your G-spot. G for girth-growing, I mean. Noodle soups, noodle and rice dishes and a lot of jook (photo: http://bit.ly/Hitl30). I went for the bargain-priced $4.95 Stewed Beef Brisket & Wonton Noodle Soup mostly because it had the longest name which in my simple mind, meant more ingredients per spoonful (photo: http://bit.ly/1eLC1uT). Good, not great with just enough wonton, bok choy, and beef to meet the daily minimum belly satisfaction requirements. So Yin can Du and so can you, and he may not have to teach. And as Woody says, those who can't teach, teach gym. How ya doin', Mr. Fiorello?

FOOD - 3 stars...middling bowl of wonton soup but it still works for a hearty appetite
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...did I mention that it's clean?
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...standard walk-bys
TOTAL - 3 stars...Yin can Du...seriously
author: Ed U.

description:
None of the bowls are over $6 and the service is super fast.

It's so good I've gone 2 days in a row and I've gotten the same thing: Roast Duck Wonton Noodle Soup.

It's worth the walk from SOMA!

CASH only obviously
author: Dorris W.

description: Bad services ! The waitress saw us ( I was holding a baby ) and still keep talking to one customer about 3 minutes . I was stand there like a fool . Finally got a table . No high chair or booster for the child . Will not go again .
author: Eddie S.

description:
Cheap comfort food in a CLEAN Chinatown shop! The boyfriend and I ordered the stewed beef and wonton noodle soup for $4.95 each! I regret not getting any noodles because the portions were on the small size, will remember for next time. The bf suspected his ho fun were packaged rather than fresh, but no biggie. The wontons were also smaller but tasted like fresh homemade ones with thin skin and firm filling. The broth and beef really hit the spot! I wanted to order some rice so I can have something with which to finish that tasty flavorful broth.

We actually ended up also ordering a plate of gai lan w/ oyster sauce, a rice plate with steamed spare ribs in black bean sauce, and a cold milk tea.  The gai lan was steamed well with a nice crisp still.  The rice plate was passable, more black bean flavor would've been nice, but still a pretty good deal for about $5. The cold milk tea had a good obvious flavor as well as a string sweetness from the condensed milk.

The entire meal came out to $26, including tip.  Staff is friendly and service is swift. Yelp has the closing time incorrect, Yin Du actually closes at 7:30 but many parties snuck in and still received service. 

Can't wait to come back and try out their duck and wonton noodle soup... and their congee too! Might as well, so cheap! =D

Sorry, lastly but most importantly, CASH ONLY!
author: Jennifer T.

description: Not bad.  Not great,  but not bad.  Woke up craving some braised beef, wonton and noodle soup.  Checked on yelp then headed over to the establishment.  For $5.75 a bowl it is hard to find anything really wrong.  The soup was flavorful.  The noodles were firm and chewy.  The wontons were plump and seasoned good.  The braised short rib, though flavored well was slightly tough.  Expect typical china house service and attitude, as well as cleanliness and decor.  Again, not great, but not bad.
author: Trevor A.

description:
My Chinese friend took me here as she claimed the beef brisket noodle soup was a specialty. I have to say...the broth was fantastic, the noodles were fantastic, and the beef tasted fantastic when it wasn't attached to a piece of fat. 

Definitely coming back as the won-ton noodle soup looked fantastic too.
author: Mi M.

description:
Super cheap and yummy! I ordered a bowl of wonton soup with braised beef, which cost less than $6. It was simple and home-y, and soooo satisfying. The portions aren't huge, but you can size up or order more things, especially since the prices are so low. Service was decent too. 

I'd definitely come back!
author: Abby S.

description:
Egg noodle wonton soup heaven awaits for $5 a bowl.  -complimentary hot jasmine tea to get your palette going and friendly service from start to completion.  It's quite the clean and tidy hole-in-the contrary to the majority of less than stellar establishments in Chinatown.

If you'd like to indulge in something other than soup noodles, they have some tasty looking clay pots, fresh dumplings and appetizers here.  If only my stomach was larger and my metabolism faster.  I relished my simple, hearty roasted duck, wonton noodle soup with bok choy all the way down to the white at the bottom of my bowl.  The broth was free of saturated oils and salt overload.  I left cotton mouth free.  So I can attest to the absence of MSG.  Just pure natural goodness in your belly.

Next time I'm in the neighborhood looking for breakfast, you're the one Yin Du.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: The only 2 stars is for the food I like, but not for the service. Old Aunts waitress, PLEASE DON'T share our table without any asking, that's freaking RUDE, and freaking Awkward. Let's imaging that there are two strange ppl sitting in front of you, how could you eat? We don't need any like Best Service and I never expected that, but at least show a Little bit respect, Open your mouth and ask we want to share table with other people or not. Unlike!
author: Waymond W.

description: Amazing just purely amazing went to the restaurant next door suck compared to this place this place is amazing once again
author: Jose V.

description:
I brought my parents to this restaurant.  My mother is a wonton fiend but the wontons were just ok.  However!  We all raved about the Beef Brisket with Rice Noodles (Ngow Lam Fun).  It is soooo tender!  Even my mom (who's super critical of Beef Brisket) can't believe the taste and tenderness.  Because of the taste of the brisket, the soup was pretty darn tasty as well.

Minus one star because I went past their kitchen and saw how many scoops of MSG they put in.  You already know that a Chinese restaurant uses a ton of MSG, but when you actually see it - it's makes it extra real!!  

Special note:  During busy times, you'll need to be ok with communal seating, just like in China/Hong Kong.  It's ok.  All the cool kids (and adults) do it.
author: Nutmeg Y.

description:
Cash only!  But worth every penny!

Amazing pork and shrimp wonton!  Generously portioned and great flavor.  We like the braised beef and roasted duck wonton noodle soups.   

Tried the pork and preserved duck egg congee.  Looks like they use a short grain rice. Tender pieces of pork and nicely garnished with slivered ginger, cilantro and green onion. 

My new go-to for wonton noodle soup!!  Sorry Hon's Wun Tun House!

P.S. Front of their menu indicates they don't use any MSG
author: Jennifer I.

description: Great wonton house. They have a picture of soup on the glass wall out front, but when I asked for it, they said, "Only picture, don't have." Funny. Anyhow, their wontons are made well, delicate noodles casing, small shrimp inside with pork, nice flavor. Excellent 'al dente' noodles. Roast pork was tender, not old, and had a great taste, and they put Chinese broccoli in the soup too. Decent price, not cheap, not expensive.
author: Brian J.

description: They practically only speak Chinese here.  However, it is easy enough to order something.  You just need to say what you want or point to it on the menu.  The restaurant is not exceptionally clean, but the food is decent given that you pay 5.50 for a bowl of wonton noodle soup.  I'll be coming back because it's so cheap, the soup has the right amount of salt, the noodles are al dente, and the wontons are shrimp + pork based.
author: Alexander P.

description:
If you like decent portions for less than $5, this is a great place to go.

The restaurant is just off of the touristy Grant Ave, but I walked in and it seemed only native Chinatown residents went there. I didn't expect much in the way of service, and when no one caught my eye and pointed me to a table, I sat at the only empty one that had just cleared up. In fact, I was a little surprised when someone came to wipe my table and give me a cup of tea. After that, I ordered the standard wonton noodle soup, as an older chinese man came to share my table with me. That was a bit of a surprise, but we mostly minded our own business.

The soup came out pretty quickly, in a pretty large bowl (not as big as most Pho places, but it pretty big). Compared to Hon's Wun Tun restaurant, I'd say Yin Du wins on the existence of vegetables in soup, but loses as far as noodles, wontons and broth go. The noodles didn't absorb as much of the broth's flavor, and the wontons were much softer and ready to fall apart, compared to the chewier texture I like better.

In all, if you value price and a hearty meal over service, then this place deserves 4.5 stars! If you get upset about poor service, this probably isn't the place for you.
author: Matt W.

description:
Tasty, cheap! Got the wonton + bbq pork (chasiu) wonton noodle, also comes with some gai lan in the broth. Only $5.25! Delicious, filling.  Drank a bunch of broth without feeling greased out or completely dehydrated afterward. + a side of gai lan, perfectly al dente. F

Friend got the brisket plate noodles. Beef looked not great quality. 

Would come again!
author: Annie M.

description: Hole-in-the-wall limited dim sum.
author: Dean L.

description:
I have no idea what people are talking about when they claim this place is a "hole in the wall." The holes in my walls certainly don't have clean wooden floors and shiny mirrors.

Brisket wonton noodle soup is definitely the thing to get here, with the main attraction being the springy noodles themselves. Stretchy and al dente, they're a good match for Hong Kong streetside shacks (now speaking of hole in the wall joints...). 

The brisket itself takes second place, largely because they're cut into chunks of meat just a little too small to be interesting, and the tendon-y squishy bits of beef aren't quite there. Very soft and probably fell off some bone, as reviewers say, but give it to me in a more hefty way!

The wontons aren't worth your time. For the cost, it makes sense that they can't really pack it with shrimp, but even the pork filling seems mealy and underflavored. 

Service is speedy and not really a wait.
author: Kevin L.

description: We walked all over Chinatown in the rain, looking for something that didn't have "health advisory warnings" and could offer vegetarian and seafood options. Ended up here -- big mistake! Nothing much to choose from. Go here if you want old school down and dirty soup noodles where you share a table and everything is super cheap. Questionable meat sources. That kind of thing. I give it 2 stars because I kinda liked the joint. Don't go expecting a smile from the staff or anything approaching cleanliness or health. But the people you sit next to are usually cool. If they would even have one vegetarian soup noodle or dumpling option, I'd be so happy I would upgrade this review to 5 stars, I promise you! :)
author: Herman S.

description:
Is it just my luck? 
I had a very bad experience at this store today.

Table was dirty when we sit down, i waived at one of the waitress and ask her to clean
the table, She never came. Although I have to say, we Chinese often do tolerate this kind of dirty and rude places for good food.

One waitress came to take our order. I said, #4 wonton beef soup.
She pointed to a picture and repeated back, "wonton beef", which is not the one i ordered but couple dollars more.
I said, "No, #4 with soup." We were playing this game back and forth couple of times.

Our next table got the same treatment, they want hot tea,
She brought 3 ice tea ,which is not free, then she argued with those young men,
 that they ordered it.

Price was cheap on the menu, it was under $6 for my wonton soup, 
but , it tasted like soy sauce water, no flavor at all.
It was a very disappointing dish for me.

My son ordered a $8 dish,  portion was so small compare with the picture they advertise on the wall and at the front door. He came home and still feeling hungry.

Spend your dollar somewhere else, this is San Francisco, you can do better.
author: chao-ying w.

description:
7/25/13 Late Lunch

Came to Chinatown to drop off some pants at Mrs Ma Alteration on Stockton. I walked by Yin Du and stopped for Wonton Lo-Mein. The restaurant is fairly new and is clean inside with about 6 tables. 

*Wonton Lo-Mein ($5.50): Soup is usually served on the side. The menu claims no MSG is used but the soup has MSG so I stopped after a couple spoonfuls. The noodle is the Hong Kong-style thin noodle. It's springy and not too tough. The wontons are somewhat disappointment. Wrapper is thin but a bit mushy. Very little shrimps in the filling, mostly pork. 

I like how the noodle is not spattered with oyster sauce. It's a decent lunch for the price you pay but not great. 

Cash only.
author: Matt Y.

description: The owner is scum. Avoid at all costs. Rude service,  hostile, and will charge you tip on top of your bill.
author: Kenny O.

description:
Cheap prices and decent food.  The wontons were perfectly cooked and the broth was nice.  I've eaten there 3 times now and I enjoy it.  The service can be harried, but they are friendly.  

Is this the best broth, wonton, dumpling place?  Nope.  But for $5-6 bucks, it can't be beat!
author: Gary O.

description: If you want tasty and affordable dumpling and wonton soups this is your place. It is not fancy and you may sit with strangers, buts it's delicious and authentic.
author: J S.

description:
Best spots for some basic Cantonese cuisine essentials: congee, wonton noodles, and pork (chasu) rice.

It's cheap, clean, and fast. It also tastes great! What more do you want?
author: Victor W.

description:
Yin Du Wonton House is a tenish  tabled, clean, open grilled, eatery.

menu: noodle soup, noodle dishes, congee, rice plates, sides

eats: stewed beef brisket won ton soup(4.95)
-broth had a few strands of greens, green onions, lots of msg.
-6 pieces won ton with pork filling
-small pieces of lean beef briskets
-culinary fare average, fresh tasting.
-cashier suprised i didn't want noodles.

footnotes:
-food portions small, therefore lower price
-very fast service, food in 5 minutes (premade?)
-msg aftertaste.
author: Victor G.

description: My son found a fly in his wonton noodle soup!!!!    Gross!!!! We were nice to the waitresses, paid for our food, and still gave them a tip, but places like this need to shut down for health reasons.  The other soups we ordered were probably from the same batch of broth and already contaminate by the fly as well, but we had already eaten most of it.  Eeeewwww!  Gross!  Totally lost my appetite!
author: Yelper Y.

description:
Cheap and Tasty Wonton Noodle Soup! 
What i liked about this place was that the menu was very simple and ofcourse, the prices were cheap!

You won't be paying anymore than $5 for a bowl of wonton noodle soup! The portion size was a bit smaller but you get a good amount for the price you pay for! 

This place reminds me of the quality and price of what i would get in Hong Kong!  I don't know any one that would complain about the food,price,service!

Definitely a must try!
author: Adam L.

description:
The noodles were firm, but the wontons and broth were both uninteresting. The broth was bland and lacked the seafood component that's vital to wonton noodle soup. The wontons needed more shrimp and seasoning. They had no umami presence, and the flavor just kind of fell flat. 

At the end of my meal, I saw the waitress bring a tasty looking beef stew over rice to another table. If you ever stumble upon this little restaurant, you should try that instead.
author: Nei N.

description:
Niu lam fun 牛腩粉 (stewed beef brisket with fun?) is amazing. Make sure to get fun not noodle. The best I've ever had. Quality meat, extremely flavorful, nice fun. Since prices are low, consider tipping more even though it's a casual restaurant. 

Wonton not that great. Get what I suggested.
author: Audrey L.

description:
I went her based on the Yelp reviews, visiting from Los Angeles.
Really quite mediocre, to be honest. We had the wonton noodles and porridge. I've had much, much better before.
author: Jeff J.

description:
Showed up here while on my hike through a chunk of northern San Fran. 

The restaurant was very clean and prices are very reasonable.  Reasonable to the degree that I felt like I should have been charged more for my stewed beef brisket & wonton noodle soup.  The food is served to you at your seat while you enjoy some pre-dinner green tea.

It was just what I needed after a few mid day pints and before my trip to Toronado.

If you are looking for a quick meal in Chinatown and want to save money for beer, definitely consider Yin Du.
author: Brian K.

description:
Very simple wonton noodles with duck and Chinese broccoli. Super cheap for SF - about 5 bucks for a bowl of noodle soup. They've got other noodles too, but we like the wonton. Sometimes the duck has feathers still, so we stopped getting our noodles with duck, but it tastes great even without. 

Would rate higher if they gave more food. We're full upon leaving but get hungry not too long after. 

The owner is really nice and though he doesn't speak much English, he can still help you choose the right dish. 

We always come here when we're looking for a cheap, simple meal.
author: Mark T.

description:
Solid 5 stars!

The food is excellent.  The stewed beef brisketis unlike any other you can get out there-life changing!

The wontons were freshly made and freshly cooked.  When we walked in, we saw two big mounds of fresh wonton's being wrapped and, when we ordered our wonton soup, into the pot they went.

The gailan greens are young greens.  They came out perfectly cooked with the right amount of crunch.  The chef also does not overdress the greens with oil and hoisin as many Chinese restaurants do.  It's actually a healthy dish even after cooking it the Chinese way.

The thing I enjoy most about this restaurant is the owner.  As I left, I told him this place was so good he could afford to raise the prices a little (with rent, health insurance, labor, and material costs).  The dishes right now are between $4-$7/dish and they are located in the heart of San Francisco.  

The owner replied that a lot of elderly Chinese from Chinatown come here and can only afford that.  A business owner with a heart-what a rare find!  

In any case, come eat here to support this amazing business owner and encourage him to raise prices.  Him and his family work way to hard to just break even with everyday living costs.  (Maybe encourage him to have a discounted senior menu for the older folks).

Great restaurant!!!
author: Jacqueline K.

description:
The beef in the beef wonton noodle soup is mind-blowing.

Wonton noodles themselves are perfectly chewy.

Wonton itself is not all that flavorful.

Price can't be beat. $4.30 for a bowl.
author: G P.

description:
Brand new and the place is near empty on a Sunday evening...this should tell you something...but we had to try it for ourselves.

Nobody greeted us although there were plenty people working there and a few "friends and family" sitting near the counter.  We grabbed one of the empty tables and checked out the simple menu.  Soon after, someone brought over two cups of hot tea (oddly the tea tasted like coffee) but she was never to be seen again. With the open kitchen, we counted 6-7 at any given time.  Not sure what they were doing and a bit irritated that nobody came to take our order.  After watching them busy doing nothing, I told one of the guys walking by that we were ready to order.  We were going to order a few side dishes but given their speed, we opted for only a wonton noodle and a plain dumpling.  Good thing because neither was good so glad we didn't waste more dollars and stomach space at this place.

Two problems: 1) they didn't cook or rinse the noodles right so the broth started to get yellow from it; 2) the wonton and dumpling are so plain and generic that it's no better than what I can make at home.  When they are supposed (at least I thought) to be master in wonton, this is a serious failure.

Price is lower than other joints but you've been warned.
author: Gloria H.

description: I went there for a couple of time.  Today I order beef brisket with rice noodle . They increase their price very fast.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Food: 4
Decor: 2
Service: 2

Came here for lunch since I was craving some wontons.

1. Beef brisket wonton noodle
~Pretty good. Beef was cooked nicely, and the wontons and noodles were all good. Portion was just right.

Service was okay.
author: David L.

description: Wife and kids wanted noodles. Was s great find very clean restutant.  It was good food and a great stop on our San Francisco joiyney.
author: Greg W.

description: Simple Cantonese noodle and congee place that is yummy and cheap. I had the beef brisket and wonton noodle, which I thought tasted great for the price. Expect a lack of service, like most Chinatown places, but that's also what makes it efficient and fast.
author: Ingrid C.

description:
We got the beef brisket wonton noodle soup and the chicken congee. 

If "wonton" is in the name of your restaurant, you should have the best wontons in the neighborhood. The noodles were a little too soggy and soft, and the wonton skin was flimsy (both overlooked). The flavoring had all the promises of being great but there is a strange off putting aftertaste. 

I even felt like I lost my appetite after a few bites. I left without feeling satisfied with my meal. 

The congee itself was tasty. The added chicken was tender, but something was off about the taste. There are slivers of raw ginger in the congee, which I enjoyed but may not be for everyone.
author: Andy C.

description: Honestly, this place is really cheap but I found the food to be very bland (and the curry fishball was cold). Maybe moved here from New York and they have much better Chinese food...still looking for SF's very large Chinatown to wow me.
author: Leo C.

description: This place was perfect for an inexpensive noodle house experience. Be ready for crowds and being seated at a table full of strangers. The rice noodle soup with stewed beef and Chinese broccoli (guylon) was the best dish they have to offer in my opinion.
author: H M.

description:
Truthfully, the one thing that drew me to come into this restaurant is the huge picture of a wonton noodle soup plastered on the window. That picture just looks perfect. (Kind of like judging a book by its cover...) 

Upon walking into the restaurant, there is a huge "cash only" sign so you can't say that you weren't warned that they do not accept credit. 

The restaurant has enough tables for us to get seated right away during lunch which was great cause I was starving! I opened the menu and discovered the cheap prices of all the dishes, $4.30 for a wonton noodle soup? It can't get any better than that! The wontons were delicious, you get 6 small ones, most restaurant give you 5 normal sized ones, so I guess that is what the extra one is making up for. 

Service was fast, probably cause most people order wonton noodle soups here and cooking these noodle soups are pretty quick anyways. 

I would recommend this restaurant if you're craving wonton soups.
author: Maybo L.

description:
Probably my 10th time here now and each time I come here, I always get the wonton beef stewed noodle soup. They are to die for. 

Everything on their menu is listed under $6. They have spot on quality taste, quick turnaround, clean restrooms, and a very comforting environment. 

Highly recommend if you're looking for a quick fill up at super lighting service, great quality and prices you can't beat!
author: Fion H.

description:
This is my favorite gem of chinatown. It's unpretentious and has very affordable traditional Hong Kong food that transports me straight to nostalgia. I always get either the congee or the wonton with beef brisket. It's really savory and great portioned. No msg.

Every time I come here its always filled with the older customers. I'm usually the odd young one out. However, this place could easily be made popular if more young people tried their noodles. Place is small and can get packed with locals. They will sit next to you if there are no spots left. Think of this place as a bus or a communal eating cafeteria. 

I love this place and I hope you give it a try. Honestly, it's under 5 bucks so why not.
author: Rosalind W.

description: Yelpsters, thank you for introducing us to this place. We wanted noodles, we were staying near Chinatown and Yin Du did not disappoint. It's not a tourist spot, it was full of folks from the neighborhood. We shared a table with a family and we basically pointed to what they were having and asked for the same. Delicious food and so inexpensive. It was ten bucks for two of us. If you are looking for authentic Chinese noodles in SF, this is the spot.
author: Rocky F.

description:
I've passed by this restaurant every time I am on Pacific Ave. Came here today since I was craving for wonton noodles. My mom ordered the beef brisket noodles and both items were delicious.

Another nice spot for wonton noodles in Chinatown. The food here is good and service is very efficient. If you are in this area, for breakfast, brunch, lunch, snack or dinner, then this is another spot to turn to. It's really good that this restaurant is open until 8 pm. Some of the dining establishments in this area are open until 6 pm or 7 pm. Not a lot of them are open past 8 pm!

After passing by this area, I'm glad I finally made a stop here for something to eat. The entire facility looks very new and modern. This place looks very clean in consideration of all the dining options available in this area.
author: Bennett W.

description:
Yin Du is consistent, good, inexpensive and quick. They simply hit the mark so that's why I go there most weekends. The food is nicely arranged which makes it photogenic -- have you noticed how good most of the Yelp pictures are of their food? Even though they're rushed it also shows their attention to detail. 

The brisket is good and goes well with the rice dish, the dry noodle dish, or as part of the won ton noodle soup.

The won ton noodle soup might not be the best around but it's pretty good, like among the top 10%.

With many of the dishes they include a stalk or two of yu choy, which is fresh tasting and always perfectly done. Many restaurants add the side vegetable as an after thought so it may be overcooked or a less good tasting vegetable, but the yu choy that Yin Du includes is always perfect and another example of their attention to detail.

There have been some dishes I was less fond of, like the curry chicken rice or the beef tendon noodles, but even so they weren't bad. They serve a good meal every time.
author: John W.

description: I had number four, wontons were amazing broth was amazing perfect 10!! And check for two entrees was 13 bucks! Holy crap I'm so satisfied!!ooiZ
author: Randi L.

description: Really really cheap and tastes quite good. Didn't feel great afterwards but that may be the salt overload. On the fence if I would go back, but it does taste great!
author: Ben G.

description: Pork Wonton noodles not bad. Good quantity of noodles with good texture; char siu and wonton were ok. Liver jook not so good. Adding a star because of price -- decent cheap food. Maybe stick to noodle dishes.
author: Bruce C.

description: I used to really really LOVE this place going there twice a week but since it changed ownership HORRIBLE.  I wanted to give this place one last time so i went in 2 weeks ago first my bowl had dried food on the outer rim YUCK same thing with the chop sticks. A customer was leaving the new owner looked on the table and told him his tip was NOT ENOUGH!!!  I was gobsmacked  never had I heard that before. Next a young woman asked the owner for a bowl who is now at a table eating her food but there are 3 tables with food still on it.  She tells her to go into kitchen underneath the counter let's say she couldn't find a bowl. The owner never stopped eating or got up to help. This new owner eats in front of customers when she was taking my order not cool. She belittles people for not giving a bigger tip. The overall cleaniness has declined and I've eaten in Chinatown for over 40 years so I KNOW CHINESE RESTAURANTS NOT KNOWN FOR BEING CLEAN.She does't seem to care I was a loyal customer for 3 years NO MORE  sorry i gave it one final last chance. Also the food quality has droppped.so sad ....
author: Jo K.

description:
How could I ever give this place a bad rating when everything is so cheap and fulfilling? I swear that everything on the menu was under $6. So worth it. 
The broth of the wonton was flavorful and the wonton was great.
If you ever just want a cheap soupy fix, this is the place to go.
author: Katherine L.

description: Great prices, fast service, pretty tasty food.  What more can you ask for?  This place to me, is a semi-gem in Chinatown.  They are pretty nice and try to give you your order ASAP.  This is cash only so be prepared.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Best congee in the city! My friend and i have been looking for a real home-cooked porridge like Asian style and now we got this spot. 
The brisket beef wonton noodle soup is pretty tasty. 
One plus thing is they open really early, 7am, not at 9.
author: Phuong P.

description: The wonton's are subpar; however, the beef brisket is magical and so are the noodle and broth.  Honestly you cannot beat the price for the food.
author: Anthony C.

description: Cash ONLY! Be prepared! We had some great congee and the roast duck wonton soup. Super affordable and fast!
author: Yen H.

description: Authentic. Tasty. Curry. Won tons. Brisket. Staff hustles. A line out the door. And nothing beats the price.
author: Douglas L.

description: After reading the feedback, I was so looking forward to this.  I was disappointed.  The quality of the wonton was the same as the ones I make - BAD.  The noodles were soggy also.  Come on. You are supposed to be professionals.  This was such a big let down that I left.  If you are looking for good wonton,  this is not it.  Moving on. Thank you.
author: Randall C.

description:
They're not excellent.
They don't sell the best wonton or the best noodle.
BUT they I can guarantee they sell the best wonton noodle soup of a decent portion under $6. Those are virtually non-existent.
So if you have any complaints, you're probably a cheap a** who thinks you can buy the world with $5.
By the way, their congee is very nice. I got the one with chicken, and it was exactly like how I had it in Asia.
BIG PLUS for not using MSG in their cooking.
author: Alan T.

description: Good wontons, friendly service, and I enjoyed the complimentary hot tea they serve upon arrival. CASH ONLY. The noodles were mediocre. The chinese broccoli with oyster sauce is delicious and big enough to share between two people. very small restaurant but we came at 4 pm so plenty of seating.
author: Anne L.

description:
If you're looking for a small portin of food this is the place to come. The resturant is small and if it start packing up you'll have to share your table with others, but this place is clean compare to other places in Chinatown.

I got the wonton noodle soup with duck and when it came out I was like ugghh where's the rest of the food? I had a whole bowl of noodles, 3 wonton, and 3 small small pieces of duck. I didn't enjoy the noodles but the wonton and the duck was pretty good. I wish they had side order of the duck because it didn't satisfied my need for wonton noodle soup with duck.   

The entire meal only cost us 4 $23.00! Can't beat that anywhere else beside chinatown.
author: Kim N.

description: Disappointed in the quality and the quantity of the wonton noodle soup here at Yin Du. The price is right, but I wouldn't come again to fulfill my wonton noodle soup cravings. It is cheap and clean, not very packed on a Sunday morning. I shared my table with an old Chinese man, no complaints here, it keeps the experience authentic. If only the meal was as authentic! Cash only.
author: Michael C.

description:
The best won ton noodle I've had in the city. Everything is handmade from scratch. You literally watch them wrap the wontons before they cook it. The wontons are big and plump and the wrapper is silky smooth and just thin enough. The noodles are also not too heavy and they don't give you too much so it doesn't overpower the wontons. They also throw in some veggies, which is always a plus. The broth is also amazing - so simple, but so flavorful.

The staff is really friendly, too. And the prices are fantastic. Can't really ask for anything more except that I wish they stayed open later.
author: Jamie C.

description: Really cheap, food is what you'd expect, service is bare bones and if you don't flag people down good luck, seems pretty authentic. If you don't mind the service go for it!
author: Kate S.

description: Cheap, ok noodle house in Chinatown. Not too much to it. $5 for a bowl of wonton noodles. We just wanted Asian noodle soups and did a quick yelp search. It's whatever. Cheapie and ok.
author: Kathleen C.

description: Cleaner than most places. Decent food. Great prices. I've had fish jook, pork and egg jook, won ton har fun, and won ton har fun wtih gnow lam (beef brisket). All decent and under 7 bux!
author: Angela L.

description:
Pretty good food. 
Like others have mentioned, cash. No ice for the soda, just a straw and a can.
I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.
author: Michael B.

description: Reasonably priced fresh wonton noodle soup. Easy to find lots of parking nearby just remember this place as well as the parking nearby are CASH ONLY.
author: Maria B.

description:
It's very rare that I find an AUTHENTIC Chinese restaurant that's both 1) clean and 2) has good customer service.
Don't get me wrong, I'm from the San Gabriel Valley, where Chinese restaurants are aplenty on each block, but Yin Du has some of the best wonton noodle soup that I've ever had (and trust me, I've had too much for my own good)

+ FIRST IMPRESSIONS: After a fun-filled, but long, weekend in the Bay, I've been feeling a little under the weather. My sister suggested Yin Du, calling it the "best place for wontons because their food is so drool-worthy," to make me feel better.
We walked a short distance to get to Yin Du, and this place is a true hole-in-the-wall. Literally, amongst all the bustling markets and hoards of Asian grandparents looking for the freshest produce, it can be pretty hard to spot Yin Du and its rather small hanging exterior sign from the street
Walking in with a partially stuffed nose, I could still smell the strong fragrance of the wonton soups and congees wafting from the back kitchen. The place was so clean, especially since my expectations were much lower than what I was given

+ SERVICE: The owner of this restaurant is totally adorable! We walked in, and although the counter is towards the back of the door, he was super vigilant with greeting and seating us.
Since we beat the lunch rush, we got to choose our table and he was fine with that. 
He brought us tea, with a smile on his face, took our orders, with a bigger smile on his face, and brought out our food, with a HUGE smile on his face. And it wasn't one of those "oh I guess I should smile out of courtesy" smiles, it was one of those smiles that made you feel like he was a long-lost relative who couldn't wait to sit down and catch up with you.
The older lady isn't as friendly, but it might be because she doesn't speak much English from what I understood? I asked her for a refill on tea, but she came out with another set of napkins/utensils, looked at our table, stopped halfway, and headed back to the kitchen, eventually coming out with the tea pitcher. 
She did bring out our bill, with perfect timing even with all of the lunch rush coming in!

+ FOOD:
okay when my sister was telling me how amazing their roast duck wonton noodle soup was, I thought, "oh it's probably pretty good," but I definitely wasn't expecting, "WOW THIS IS BLOWING MY MIND AMAZINGLY GOOD" type of good
+ ROAST DUCK WONTON NOODLE SOUP (10/10: A+++++++) and now we break down the dish into its components:
- Broth: so extraordinarily flavorful. I felt A LOT better by the end of the day, even with my horrible cold (probably because I slurped all of it up, oops)
- Noodles: they were so well cooked! chewy, yet not tough to the point where you wanted to spit them out and give up, which happens very often with me, the pickiest eater ever
- Roast duck: SO GOOD. the pieces literally MELTED onto my tongue, something that I find rarely happens with Chinese roasted duck that can be so poorly cooked that the texture becomes similar to that of rubber. BUT NOT AT YIN DU!!
- Wontons: I've had so many wontons from different places where either 1) there is little to no filling so all you're eating is boiled dough or 2) the filling is still frozen solid and not consistently cooked so you're basically eating a chunk of frozen meat, as the outside skin falls off
HOWEVER, the wontons from Yin Du changed my life as they were so soft and delicious and it was like eating little bundles of joy, tightly wrapped into a soft dumpling skin
- Bokchoy: there was only one, but it was boiled to perfection, so you wouldn't be struggling with a huge steam/leaf in your mouth

+ OVERALL: Amazing authentic Chinese food. Super clean for a hole-in-the-wall restaurant. Friendly/passionate owners.
And best of all? CHEAP PRICES. That's right! One wonton bowl was ONLY $5! (you can't even get a movie ticket for that low nowadays)
author: Hennie N.

description:
Came here on Friday for dinner, ordered wonton noodles, beef brisket noodles, and congee.

Congee and beef brisket noodles were really good! I was more interested in the Wonton noodles given all the positive reviews on Yelp. Thought it was a bit lacking though, average sized wontons and noodles were just alright. 

Good price though for 5 dollars you get a bowl of noodles.
author: Janice C.

description: Took my wife and 8-yr old here for lunch based on Yelp reviews. We were looking for something we could trust in Chinatown. So glad I did. We need a quick, filling lunch and not looking to pay tourist rates. We had the Wonton soup, which tastes great, with two green teas and a Sprite. Total bill was $20 that included tip.
author: Sean B.

description: We want to find a yummy and fast restaurant during lunch time and saw this place with 4 stars on yelp. No wait when we arrive at 12:30. awesome! we ordered wonton with beef brisket noodle soup. It looks great when it arrived. Soup tasted good and noodle is chewy. GREAT! however, when i tasted the wonton, it's just not right. Wonton is suppose to be big and well seasoned. However, i just ate a piece of shrimp plus pork. thats it so wonton is not my favorite here. Beef brisket/tender tasted good but they only gave you the small pieces and felt like it's just leftover portion. it suppose to be at least 2 to 3 whole piece of beef brisket or tender so i was firely disappointed. it's just a simple things to serve but seems like it's not to the standard yet.
author: Eva L.

description: Love the food and affordable. You know it's good whenever it's a smaller place and the staff do not know English well. We got the beef tenderloin with noodles and it was delicious!
author: Elena K.

description:
Yin Du didn't du it for us. Came to lunch here based on other yelp reviews. My family of four got three different dishes. The dumpling soup, no description on the menu, features various fish inside the dumping. There was a shell inside one and the fish would have made better bait. All the dishes were bland, and the noodles were, in all of my family's opinion (who are adventurous eaters), disgusting. We paid for our meal (cash only as per requested) and left. On the way out, our waitress took my 12 yo step daughter (last one out) by the arm and stated that we needed to leave a tip. As part of our plans, we then went to the fortune cookie factory nearby and my 9 year old step-son realized he had left his water bottle at Yin Du. He went in by himself to get it and the staff then demanded $2 for its return and back-handed slapped him remarking that we didn't tip! Needless to say, this didn't go over well with my husband who promptly retrieved our property and they demanded a tip again! Unbelievable! Should we have left a tip? Maybe. We usually tip, but after the experience, we didn't feel compelled. 

At any rate, judge for yourselves. But, we absolutely do not recommend this place.
author: Cyn M.

description: My friend and I stumbled across this hole in the wall noodle spot after spending the afternoon shopping in Union Square. This is the best wonton noodle soup I've had. There is so much flavor, hits the right spot, and the prices aren't bad either. They don't have any frills but if you're just looking for wonton noodle soup, go here.
author: ivy t.

description:
Came here for breakfast. Their roast duck wonton noodle soup (#9) definitely hit the spot. Only two small pieces of duck, but they were juicy with crisp skin.  The wontons (shrimp/pork inside) were excellent, the egg noodles were pretty good, and it came with some veggies. 

It's extra cheap at 5$ a bowl and comes out pretty fast. They also have a congee menu which looked good.
author: Haitao M.

description:
I have been to this place a few times and always feel strange that even when there is a long line waiting for tables, the restaurant won't provide a way for customers to put down their names to wait for tables. Occasionally I see people bypass those waiting and sit themselves by first disguised looking for friends etc. Some restaurant operators use this no-system system to sit their preferred customers or friends; I don't know if it is the case here or not. For sure without a name board, a lot more of my folks (some Chinese from mainland China are uncivilized) will jump the line if they find the opportunity.

Today I went there with a relative. During ordering, I asked the order taker, the boss (I think, he tends the cash register and seems to manage the restaurant), if they have dip-fried bread stick (the kind of bread very popular for southern Chinese to eat porridge with). His answer, "This is a noodle place, how could we have that!" In fact, he sells porridge there, and in fact, a lot of even small restaurant sell those sticks.

After we finished our food, we stayed on to talk. About half an hour later, the boss came over and said, "When people come to lunch, you have to leave!" His exact words, not edited, not polite. I then looked around and found, in this small restaurant, three four-seat tables and one two-seat table, empty!

Finally, if I did not miss any sign, the restaurant never inform customers that all tables are shared; suddenly a stranger sit in front of you without asking! They don't respect people there.
author: Adrian W.

description: Get the roast pork and broccoli with oyster sauce! Soo good! Our service was great, constant refills of free tea.
author: Jennifer R.

description: It's hard to find a good and fresh wonton noodle soup place. This is definitely one of the better places. The wonton noodle is very fresh and the wontons are hand made. Depending on the time of day you are there, you can see them make the wontons. The soup is very clear and isn't masked in fatty or MSG like some other places. The prices are very reasonable too. I tried a few other dishes, but if you aren't getting the wontons here, I think you are coming to wrong place. The place is pretty small, so I wouldn't recommend bringing a large crowd unless you get lucky and it's not busy. And remember to bring cash, CASH ONLY. If I'm craving wonton noodle soup and I'm in the city, I'd definitely consider this place.
author: Cal K.

description: Great wonton noodles! Don't forget the dumplings. It's so hard to find good noodles in New York -- this came close to perfection (aka Hong Kong standards according to my mom). Clean, cheap, quick.
author: Elsie W.

description:
I was starving and heading through Chinatown, so whipped out my phone and Yelp told me about Yin Du.  I headed in and was promptly shown to a table that I shared with another lady. The place is very bare bones, but absolutely immaculate.  The menu is pretty small, but when you specialize in Wontons and Noodles, you don't need a big ass menu offering a zillion different items.

My Wonton noodle soup with beef brisket came quickly, and was delicious.  The beef was a little fatty for my liking, but I managed to eat around the fat.  The wontons were so succulent and they were cooked perfectly, as were the noodles.  I am a big fan of Hun's Won Ton House, but I've always thought their broth was kind of lacking.  The broth at Yin Du was rich and very satisfying.  

In and out in fifteen minutes, bowl of soup and mug of tea came to $5, accompanied by friendly service.  

What's not to love?
author: .Hon H.

description:
I'm ABC and my point of reference is NYC Chinatown, and unfortunately I have yet to eat Chinese food in SF that I would eat again. Sorry, but Yin Du was no exception. Their noodle soup with brisket came with broth, noodles and brisket. What? Not even a sprig of cilantro? And 25% brisket, 75%gristle!?

Our dumpling and noodle soup... same story. Barely hot, nothing-special broth. Very mediocre. Nothing that warrants a recommendation.  

The only item that was decent was the Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce (gai lan), but any restaurant that can't do that right shouldn't be open. 

You can do just about anywhere and do better unless you're having trouble making your rent payments.
author: janice w.

description:
Wow, pretty good flavors for the beef noodle wonton soup, and super cheap prices.  Granted, portion size is a bit small, but still a great value.  I would totally go back.

Head to head compared to New Sun Hong King, the bowl prices are lower, but they are also smaller.  I liked the flavors here just as much, however.

If you are on a budget and want a light meal in Chinatown at a very fair price, come here.
author: Dave N.

description: Pretty awesome noodle, even better than some of the hong Kong ones. Clean taste and the noodles are bouncy and just right for my taste. Nice and clean environment for a quickie!
author: Rodolfo Y.

description:
Last Sunday, my wife and me went to Chinatown and had had a lunch in this Restaurant. This restaurant no MSG, We order " Pig's Feet Noodle ", and coming with soup,  pig's feet which I had tried were delicious too. , we order " Chinese Broccoli W/Oyster Sauce ", it was very green and fresh.   they keep the place pretty clean. the food is good, accompanied by friendly service. Cash Only.

上週日，我的妻子和我去了唐人街，並吃午餐在這個雲吞麵店。這家餐廳沒有味精，我們叫了"豬腳麵", 和湯一同來, 豬腳，我試過是太好吃了. 我們叫了"蠔油中式西蘭花"，這是非常綠色和新鮮。他們保持地方還算乾淨。食物是好的，而且服務也不錯. 只收現金。
author: Eric W.

description:
They make good wonton noodles. I've had wonton noodles from HK, and Vancouver and these Wonton noodles are alright, good in SF standards.

They were making wontons right as we entered and the no MSG in the soup makes it even more desirable. Very fast and friendly service.

If I lived in SF, I might consider patronizing this restaurant once every two months. Parking is just a nightmare.
author: Jerry L.

description: went here for breakfast since I wanted something simple. The service was good but the only thing is that this place is cash only
author: Ngoc C.

description:
Had a hankering for some old school wonton noodle soup, so hit up Yin Du based on yelp reviews.  I ordered the wonton noodle soup with roast duck and a side of gai lan.  It definitely hit the spot.

I must say that their version of this dish is slightly more bland than I'm used to, however, after finding out that this restaurant does not use MSG, I understand and completely agree.  

Service was good, the waitress was friendly, and the price is definitely right.  The only thing I didn't like was sharing a table with 2 different sets of strangers, but I guess that is par for the course in such a small restaurant.

I will definitely be back the next time I'm in the city and need some comfort food Cantonese style.
author: Burrito M.

description: Went back w/ my whole family this time.  Everyone loved their wontons, dumplings & beef stew noodle soups.  We had couple items for the table to share: Chinese broccoli w/ beef stew sauce instead of oyster sauce (dad's idea as he's a regular, YUM!) and a steamed pork spareribs rice plate (mostly lean cuts - my fav).  They truly are the NICEST people and didn't get a bit annoyed when I came in by myself to reserve a large table and seated me right away w/ an offering of hot tea, nor did they kick us out w/ my cousin showing us her honeymoon photos after we finished eating.  Unlike many places in Chinatown, Yin Du is super clean and staff is so accommodating.  HIGHLY recommend it!!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Many Yelpers are singing in high notes for this restaurant, so I stopped by and had a tasting session specifically with their wonton noodles. I would rate the texture and quality of their noodles a 7 out of a perfect Hong Kong 10. Although the soup is not "Hong Kong" authentic, it is uniquely refreshing and tasty while MSG was not used. The wontons are very fresh, but it could be a let down if you are not used to pork wonton (lack of shrimp). The price is right. Clean open kitchen, and they wrap their wontons fresh when they are not so busy (I was there and it was 5:30 pm). I would definitely eat there again (3.5 Star).

Update: Tried out their fish congee 3 weeks later, one of the best that I have tasted in the Bay Area. A 4 Star item specific review update from me for Yin Du.
author: Mango M.

description:
I loved this place. I got the wonton noodle with duck, and even though the duck pieces were mostly bones, skin, and fat, it added an amazing flavor to the broth. If you were really committed, you could dissect away some duck meat, but it was still worth it for the added flavor. A nice piece of Chinese broccoli was also a nice touch. 

An amazing deal for just over $6. Service was friendly and fast, with communal style tables to squeeze in and get to know your neighbor. Can't wait to go back!
author: M H.

description:
Great big bowls of tasty wonton noodle soup. Bonus that it comes with veggies. They opened within the last year and I'm glad to see they are doing well since they are bit out of the way off the tourist path and Fidi lunch spot. Everyone's always been really nice and they keep the place pretty clean. 

Good, cheap Hong Kong style food. Come in and have a seat. Even if the table is occupied, if there is room, you can ask if it's ok to sit. The small casual restaurant is designed so there will be groups, but there are always singletons (grandmas and grandpas from Chinatown) having meals here and they are always ok sharing a table. 

Portions are very good for the price. Everything on their menu is decent, but I like their wonton noodle soups the best.  The rice dishes are a bit too greasy, and their congee is of the "add-on" variety (a base porridge, then ingredients added to it, rather than cooked and flavored with ingredients.)

Service isn't the speediest so don't come here in a rush expecting to zip in and out (sometimes they tend to get overwhelmed), but if you're looking for a decent casual meal, it can be had for $5 or less.
author: Kiki J.

description: What a find this place is!!! A bowl of wonton noodle soup for a little over $4.00? Very good for the price, maybe the best wonton around in SF Chinatown. Portions are on the small side of average, but with the money you saved, you can always go to the neighboring bakery to fill your tummy with more carbs.
author: Mike L.

description:
Not bad. I had the beef brisket wonton thin rice noodle soup. Also ordered curry fish balls, roast duck wonton noodle soup, bbq pork wonton noodle soup and the honey lemon drink. 

My beef brisket was tasty and flavored the soup wonderfully. The thin rice noodles were a surprise. It was silly and soft. The other dishes were ok. The soup base was ok not as flavorful as the beef brisket soup base. The honey lemon drink was ok. (I had better)
author: Alice M.

description:
Won ton soup was great! The soup was just perfect and savoy. The won tons were perfect balance of meat and shrimp. 

Plus..very clean and new!

Only downer was the hot sauce. Wish they had better hot sauce.

Great deal..only 4.95 for duck and won ton soup! Very filling!
author: Cynthia N.

description:
This is probably as good as it gets in Chinatown.  This is better than Hon's wonton house on Kearny.  When I was growing up here, there is no such thing as restaurants like these.  The less you knew about how the food was prepared, the better off you'll be.  The open kitchen allows you to see what's going on with your food.  This is a rarity in Chinatown.  The people here are from my village, Thaisan.  Very honest and hard working people with the intent to give you the best possible experience.  The owner lives in the neighborhood which gives it that sense of ...........I must support the local businesses.  

To the food.....................It's good.  Not the best I have ever had but for San Francisco, this might be the best won ton house that we have to offer.  The broth was made the way I remembered when I was a kid.  My uncle used to own On On Wonton house in Oakland.  I personally thought they made it the best.

The items they have here is limited.  Get the beef stew wonton noodles.  They are known for that here.  I've tried the curry and the jook here is only ok.  Just stick to the wonton noodles and beef stew and you'll be ok.

The portions are on the smaller side but for 4.50 a bowl, you can order 2.  As for the price, believe it or not, it's a little pricey for Chinatown.  You are probably thinking 4.50 a bowl is pricey?  Yes, it is for Chinatown pricing.  However, for the quality of food, and cleanliness of the restaurant, I would pay the higher price.

Great find in Chinatown!!!
author: jason g.

description:
Good food when they serve you. They refused me takeout because I want eating in the restaurant. Every table was full, so I had no option to eat there. Ahead of me, 4 people just ordered and received their takeout items...

I've eaten here a few times before, so hopefully I'll be served next time, otherwise I'm going to report then to the BBB. There's absolutely no reason they can't serve takeout to a single person after fulfilling for orders right before they person.
author: CMOS P.

description:
The food here is clean and simple.  A great place to stop by if you want to get some authentic Chinese food and avoid tourist traps in Chinatown.

We had the duck wonton soup, and it was savory without being too salty or overwhelming.  The few pieces of Chinese broccoli were a perfect addition to the wontons and duck.  Although the duck portion was on the smaller side, I really couldn't complain considering the dish was $6. 

The pork and rice dish was also really tasty.  The pork was lightly seasoned with an oyster sauce.  Again, the few pieces of Chinese broccoli in oyster sauce seasoning was a great addition.
author: Sharon L.

description:
They don't see many White Folks here.
But the Congee and Won-Ton rock !
author: Mark B.

description:
it is a great Chinese Wonton Noodle soup restaurant. 

ok, it is tiny but cozy, bright and ok clean. 

you can see the kitchen. 

portion is small but the price is also cheap, but great taste. you can try different things without having to pay a lot. 

as a Cantonese, I think this is a 4 star noodle restaurant. 

highly recommended if you happen to be in chinatown in SF, looking for some delicious and reasonable price lunch or dinner.
author: Ed J.

description: My go to Wonton spot in Chinatown. Fast, easy, and to the point. They offer a good variety of wonton soups and it's clean inside. Severs are attentive and you can be In and out for $7 in less than 20 minutes.
author: Darius T.

description: This place is clean, staffs are nice.  Most importantly, their wonton noodle soup is pretty good! It is cheap, and i didn't expect the portion could be big, but in fact, really big portion!
author: Mira Z.

description:
Hole in the wall joint in Chinatown. Personally I do not like coming to this area of the city cuz it's so crowded but I'll make a stop to grab a bite to eat.

Nothing fancy in anyway about this place but good noodle soup at a cheap price ($4.85). We ordered the beef stew wonton noodle soup. The beef was tender and the broth was not salty or oily like others. A solid place to warm you up and satisfy your hunger. Portions are on the smaller size so for all the heavy eaters you might need to order 2 or add an appetizer.
author: T L.

description:
The wontons weren't as shrimpy as I would have liked them, but they were fresh, tasty and very decent.

The beef brisket was awesome!  Tender, juicy and very flavorful.

Food was pretty cheap.  $4.95 for a Brisket Stew Wonton Noodle soup and $1.80 for a strong and creamy cup of milk tea.
author: Cherrie C.

description:
This is a small place in Chinatown. Came here to try out a new wonton spot clse by work.

We ordered the wonton mein and a side dish of beef brisket. The wonton noodles are ok only, but I LOVED the beef brisket! Very flavorful and very tender. I would defintely recommend to try the beef brisket if you ever come here. 

Next time I want some cheap lunch, I'll be coming back here to order beef brisket over rice! :)
author: Tiffany T.

description: Pretty good! The wonton filling needs a little work (too much white pepper and crunched on a small pice of eggshell), but broth is tasty, beef brisket stew is the bomb, and noodles are chewy. They even do a good liver and kidney appetizer if you're into that thing (heavy on the sesame oil, but sliced scallions are delightful). Better watch out, Hon's, this place is comparable in flavor, but I give it a slight edge for execution and clean decor. Service is a bit slow and you probably have to share tables during lunch rush.
author: Susan H.

description:
I was with my friend walking around in Chinatown, he suggested walking down Beckett St, an alley instead of a main street.  Spotted Yin Du Wonton Noodle as we appeared from the alley across the street.  It has a nice curb appeal, clean, bright looking in the sunlight.  What a little gem this place turn out to be for us.  The prices are low, cash only, you must get the waitress's attention to order anything, don't just sit there waiting for them to come to you, they're very busy.  Small place, may be seating for thirty customers, be prepared to share the table with other diners in this small seating capacity and highly popular place.The food we tasted was excellent.  The soup base is rich, complex, flavorful; wonton excellent with wonderful flavors.  This is probably the best wonton I've tasted.  

http://www.foodspotting.com/reviews/4054870
author: George L.

description: Food was superb! Service not so good but worth the trial anyway.  Will definitely go back again when in town.
author: John C.

description: Excellent taste and very cheap price - if you want authentic wonton noodle soup this is the right place. My favorite is the wonton noodle soup with beef stew. The seating is very crowded and you probably need to share it with someone else and the service is not as nice, but come on you are in Chinatown what are you expecting? This is just a tiny price to pay for authentic delicious food. I'm sure all the real foodies would agree!
author: Micco W.

description: The food is extremely boring.  I got wonton noodle soup and while it didn't taste bad, there was really nothing to it at all.  It was simple: 7 pieces of wonton, noodles, one piece of vegetable, and soup.  Nothing fancy, and a decent amount of food to get you 75% full - probably an appropriate fullness to be.  So if you're just looking for a simple bite to have after a long day of work or studying, this place is fine.  But like I said, don't expect anything special, meaning don't choose this place to have some big celebration or anything.  Taste wise I would actually give this place two stars because of how underwhelming the food is, but for ~$5 for a bowl of noodles it's a hard deal to beat.  So cost to quantity/quality ratio wise it's not bad.  But like I said, it's a place to just get sustenance, not have a culinary experience.
author: Chien-Rong C.

description: I love this place!  It's a tiny hole in the wall with amazing wontons.  There's a full shrimp in each wonton and the broth and noodles are very tasty.  A bowl of wonton noodle soup costs less than $5.  Everyone in there is chinese and there's not much english spoken there, but it's so worth it.  I can't recommend this place enough.  Also try the noodles with brisket or branch out into wilder things!
author: Phil D.

description:
I was looking for a porridge place in Chinatown and came across Yin Du Wonton Noodle. Although they were known for serving won ton noodles, we ordered a bowl of fish porridge and beef stew rice plate. For the price of about 4 dollars, they were good portions.. That is uber cheap! The porridge was hot, fresh, and savory. One thing they did not offer is the Chinese donuts which is usually offered to compliment the porridge.

The beef stew was mediocre. Some pieces of meat were a bit too a chewy for my liking.

 It's not likely they speak much English, but they still understand. 

The establishment is remodeled with simple menus and new seating. Though, I wouldn't say this is a good location for business as it is does not have high pedestrian traffic street. 

Cheap, good, ands gets the job done.
author: Becky Q.

description:
I came here on a Saturday around 2 and got seated right away .

I ordered the won ton noodles it was ok
Beef tendon dry noodles, tendon was good , noodles ok
Cha cheung noodles, it wasn't good
Boiled liver and kidney, tasted like liver and kidney but was drenched in oil

If I had to eat here again I would get the beef tendon over rice

Service was decent

This looks like a clean restaurant for Chinatown since everything is exposed
author: DOM d.

description: This is a small restaurant in san francisco chinatown. You know you will get authentic food when you are surrounded by locals as customers. I even got to use my frw cantonese vocabulary while ordering there. I had the fish porridge which i found the consistency really good. As a side dish the kai lan with oyster sauce was really good. I was satisfied.
author: Suying G.

description: "Wow, that's delicious." Was the first thing I said after taking a bite of the beef brisket in my wonton noodle soup. I came during the peak lunch hour and our food was served fairly quickly. This place would make it to my weekly lunch rotation if it weren't a mile away! Great noodles for less than $5 a bowl!
author: Clogozm C.

description: At 1130am, try to order Curry Beef Stew and Hot Milk Tea. Will say they have no time for making curry beef stew, can only order Beef Stew. No Hot Milk tea but Iced Milk tea. Bad customer service.
author: Alfred K.

description: Came here from all of the great yelp reviews.  We must have came in on an off day on the Mid-Autumn Moon Festival.  The staff was really overwhelmed and their stress definitely came off strong along with poor service even for Chinese standards.  Long lines at restaurants isn't anything new but I think this place never experienced it before.  The only waitress would hurriedly stick people in any seat that was open.  Getting anyone's attention was next to impossible so I had to go to the cashier each time I needed anything.  As expected, small portions but the noodle soups and dry noodles were pretty good.  Skip the combo congee.  Its burning hot, tasteless, and lacking in meat.  My tongue is still numb from it writing this review days later.
author: Jeff C.

description: I tried this little hole in the wall for the first time this past weekend. The place doesn't have a large menu, but the things to get are the beef brisket noodles and the bbq pork over rice. Both tasted decent and came at very cheap prices. The service here is friendly by Chinese restaurant standards and they servers come right away when called, which is pretty good. The only gripe I had about the place would be if they included more of the braised beef brisket in the noodle as it looked a bit skimpy when my bowl came. Otherwise, I'd totally recommend this place for those who are nearby and need a quick bite that fills you up for a good value.
author: Maurice C.

description: Ordered 3 dishes and it was still only $10 of deliciousness! The wonton noodle soup was rich in flavor and filling. I didn't care as much for the beef as other reviewers, but the soup itself was wonderful.
author: Sonia S.

description: One of the best in San Francisco.  Ingredients are fresh. The Hong Kong milk tea is great too! Definitely want to come here often for lunch but the wait can be long because it's so good!
author: Hungry D.

description: Excellent & fast service.  Delicious soup broth and noodles.  We walked in last night when they were about closing and welcomed us in.  Thank you for a great, hit the spot meal
author: Melissa I.

description: My favorite noodles.  This place is great.  Don't sit at a table for 4-6 if you're 1-2 or sometimes people will try to sit down with you.   I guess that's how people roll at yin du.  It's never happened to me but I've seen it a bunch.
author: Harlan C.

description: This place has wontons, dumplings and noodles. That's it. It's good, and it was cheap. The portions are small, but good for lunch-you won't overeat, or overspend. Cash only.
author: Chunti L.

description: Excellent... Super cheap.. Feels like I ran home for lunch and my family is from China. I can't wait come back and try more items.
author: Gypsy L.

description: Craving for wanton noodles, heres the place. Old school traditional wanton noodles soup. The skin of the wanton is so thin that it just melts right into your mouth, the broth is just the way I would want it, exactly the kind of street food you would expect in Hong Kong. There are some off menu specials and I've yet to try them, but I'm sure you could ask; I'm pretty sure its stir fried liver and kidneys with ginger and spring onions, looks like most of the tables are having at it! Anyhow, it's affordable and the portions are just enough. Think I've been here more than 6 times ever since I've moved in 2 months ago!
author: Ann Hui Y.

description: It's just a bland place. Got the soup noodles with dumpling, tried the beef noodle and shared the porridge with thousand year duck egg and pork. Everything was just.. Bland. And had this off taste to it. I couldn't like the dishes with any seasoning (pepper , salt, hot sauce) and was still hungry at the end of the meal cause I just didn't want to finish anything. Maybe it's a canto taste that I'm not enjoying? Not sure but seems like the locals enjoy the place.
author: Ruby C.

description: No kidding! The most authentic Hong Kong wonton noodle soup I've ever had in SF for less than 6 bucks.
author: Julia Q.

description: I really like the wonton here and the beef brisket. It's super cheap, too. The bad part is it closes early - closes Wednesdays - and often runs out of beef brisket at night.
author: Andy W.

description: My boyfriend and I came here after a couple days of craving won ton noodle soup. Even thought the noodles are nothing extraordinary, and their won tons are average, their broth is what made the dish. It didn't have the typical MSG taste to the soup base like how a lot of asian restaurants do. It comes in a pretty good size where we were full but not overly stuffed. My boyfriend order a side of beef and it was really good as well! I ended up dipping my noodles in the beef sauce to give my noodles a bit of flavor.
author: Jenn C.

description: They have improved! Noodles have a nice bounce, the wontons plump and juicy, and the soup full of flavor.  Super happy with it. :)
author: Jessica P.

description: This place is a winner.  Packed with locals and you might need to share a table.  The place is extremely clean and prompt friendly service.  We received a complimentary cup of hot teas when we sat down.  My sister and I ordered each a noodle bowl with wontons and noodles. We shared a plate of chicken curry and rice.  The total bill was $16.43 for two of us. What a deal!  Will definitely coming back on our next visit. Also a very clean bathroom.
author: Kathy S.

description: Had the wonton soup.  Was very tasty.  The fact they don't take credit is about the only bad thing I can say about the place.  Would go again.
author: Sang J.

description:
The service is terrible.  They don't refill your tea or water.  Also, they just drop off the food and expect you to pass around the food to the right person.  The wonton is made only with pork.  I couldn't taste any shrimp in there.  The noodle is pretty good.  It is snappy, the way I like it.  

The waitress will also ask you for a tip if she doesn't feel that it is enough.  Be ready for it.
author: E C.

description: Amazing value for damn good noodles! From now on, this is my spot! Beef brisket noodle soup and duck noodle soup highly recommended.
author: Erin P.

description: Really good congee    Pork liver and kidney combo is also really tender and fresh.  Noodle soup is good but not great.
author: Peter W.

description:
So after having finally had lunch at this place, here's the verdict:

Interior: small, simple and clean. Sits about 18 people. The place reeks of deep friend lard oil. And yes, it will get into your clothes and hair. So be prepared.
