Service: quick. took us about 10-12mins to get our food. The cafe was about 70% full at that time. the guy serving us only speaks in cantonese. Not sure if the rest of the staff will be able to understand english. 

Noodles texture i would rate 5/5 considering this is the US. Really well balanced and springy. Sauce that was used for the  noodles was well-balanced as well and i think there was a good amount of lard oil used - which probably is the the secret.

I would rate the beef brisket at about 3.5/5. Really tender, portions were really small but well seasoned.

The wanton noodles soup. Soup base was not bad, i think there was MSG in it. So i would rate the soup with a 3.5/5. The vegetables weren't overcooked and fresh. 

Wantons - BIG DISAPPOINTMENT! the skin of the wanton was soft and thin - perfect! Shrimp was fresh! But the meat was terrible! It tasted gamey/ porky! It almost had a liverish taste to it. I expected the meat to be seasoned in some sauce with garnishes like water chestnut, garlic, spring onions but i tasted none of those. I tried subsequent ones and it just tasted gamier and gamier. 

Would i return? Probably and i would try the rest of the non-wanton dishes.

BTW the establishment only accepts cash.
author: Smo S.

description: Nice bowl of good soup here, I got the wonton noodle soup and the broth was great and wontons were well prepared. I got a side order of the Chinese broccoli and my bill was like $10...pretty good deals! Portions were alright, I could've left feeling more full
author: Ross I.

description: Very good food, quick service, affordable prices. Very clean restaurant. If people are waiting, expect to sit with other small groups or singles as they utilize every empty seat.
author: Rod W.

description: Great spot, opens very early and the food was great. Defiantly try the wonton and pig feet. All broth are different depending what you order and the prices are unbeatable.
author: Min D.

description: My family and I LOVE this place and their food. Perfect mix of pork and shrimp in their wontons, the way my momma made them. Noodles and soup also very solidly delicious and perfectly cooked here. The owner is also from our village so it's cool to be able to order in Say Yup (imagine Chinese hillbilly speak) as I am the only one in my family who can speak it. Excellent service no matter what you speak. :) If you like jook, their jook has a great consistency/texture and they don't add sugar to it like some places do.
author: Grams B.

description: Saw the 4 star review so decided to give it a try.  My pork and preserved egg congee was kind of bland and left me with a weird MSG like aftertaste.  The Chinese broccoli dish was good and fresh.  But - the kicker was that even though the place looked clean, my friend had some "stomach issues" after eating her wonton noodle soup.  Service was also slow and the place only seats 28 so be prepared to share a table with strangers if there are only 2 of you.
author: B. Y.

description: Great clean shop here in Chinatown.  Impressed with service, the noodles....this is my go-to place for noodles in the area if I'm into a quick, cheap bite.  I made the "mistake" of ordering bbq rice and it appears they had some "frozen" but it came out alright. Still, I'll stick to the noodles.
author: Sonny W.

description: Almost all the dishes are below $6 and food was served very fast. The wonton noodle and pig's feet which I had tried were delicious too.
author: Sebastian N.

description: Solid wonton soup and cheap!
author: Lyly N.

description: Great wonton noodle soup. the stewed beef rice noodle soup is also a gem! The milk tea is amazing! Great value for the money
author: Wanxin C.

description: After 10+ years in Frisco, I've yet to find a good restaurant in Chinatown. Until now. Yin Du ain't fancy but it gets the job done. I went with the won ton shrimp/pork noodle soup and was not disappointed. And for $5 I'll be back. Extra pts for the white pepper
author: Tripp S.

description: Food is ok, really nothing special. However, this place is really dirty. Kitchen is open so unfortunately (or fortunately if you care about cleanliness), you can see how dirty the food preparation conditions are. The bowls and soup spoons were simply rinsed at the faucet and placed in a red plastic bin for the next customer (yikes, me). The bowls came with stains from the previous content (and previous users secretions). I was the one facing the kitchen in my party of four, so as I witnessed all this during our 30 min there, I quickly asked everyone to stop eating and we left. I should have known when we sat down, the menus are covered in grime. The conditions are pretty awful, reminds me of back country China, where one might eat in an establishment with dirt floors and poultry running around your bench. I think if this is what one is expecting, fine, eater beware. But this is San Francisco where there are food inspectors and restaurant codes, clearly not followed here.
author: Eric L.

description: This is a nice new economical meal option in Chinatown.  $4.95 for a bowl of wonton noodle with roast duck is a very good deal, though the duck is cut into quite small pieces and seem I didn't get very much.  There are many other $4.95 noodle soup options too.  Therefore, price-wise it's comparable to Hon's on Kearny Street, but that place closes at 7pm and this one stays open for an hour later.  My friend and I decide that the wonton at Hon's a better but still this is a good new option.  For us, maybe this is finally the replacement option for a meal in Chinatown we've been seeking ever since our former favorite, Hing Lung on Broadway, disappointedly closed down all of a sudden because of failing a health department inspection and not wanting to spend on fixing up.
author: H K.

description: Can't say anything about the food.  But they are closed until 4/9/15 because the family is away for vacation.
author: Shelley L.

description: Stopped in here for lunch while walking around Chinatown.  It looked busy, always a good indicator, and was a small place down Pacific rather than a large restaurant on Grant - I prefer that my patronage is helping a smaller family shop than large touristy restaurant.  The beef brisket wonton noodle soup was great!  It had a flavorful broth, noodles and wonton were done well, and the brisket was good texture (melt away while having some substance).  As a single, I did end up sitting with some other folks - family style seating - which I don't mind but be prepared if you're not used to this, even as a group of two or three you will likely have company.  I would have liked to try some other menu items but the soup filled me up good enough.  Would recommend for good soups.
author: Lightphoot _.

description: Nice duck wonton noodle soup. The place was packed with cute Chinese ladies chatting in the morning so we had to try it. Clean space with good service.
author: Vina A.

description: Service was excellent, the owner had a smile the whole time. The Chinese broccoli is a must! The wonton soup with roasted duck is a must! Our cheapest yet best meal this trip.
author: ANGELIQUE V.

description: Relatively clean restaurant with tasty noodle soup. Would definitely eat here next time we are in SF.
author: Roger A.

description: The place is a little small, but the food is good. Brisket is where it's at and the noodles are a perfect consistency. (Not soggy and a little chewy.) I've been here three times and it's great for a five dollar meal. Also, this place is a cash-only place, so make sure you've got some dough before you head in.
author: Amy N.

description: I basically picked this place out by reading other yelp reviews.  We wanted to go eat in Chinatown while in San Francisco and with little information as to where to eat we picked this place because the reviews had mentioned the cleanliness of the place and cheap eats.  The place is clean and we got out of there for about $15 bucks total (cash only).  The service was fast and very friendly.   I ordered the pork wonton noodle soup which was pretty good.  My husband ordered the beef tendon noodle which he really wasn't too happy with.  The meat was fatty and just didn't like the taste.  Overall it was ok, but I guess we really didn't know what to expect.
author: Erica M.

description: Subpar wonton noodle soup. Soup was bland. The wontons barely have any fillings in them. No shrimps, just a little pork. Noodle texture was ok. Sorry... I'm used to the NYC noodle village standards, which is comparable to HK. I'm disappointed in SF if this is considered one of the best.
author: Sharon C.

description: Went here tonight for noodle soup before going on a ghost tour.  Had the duck wonton noodle soup and my husband had the beef wonton noodle soup.  Both were very good.  We shared the bok choy and it was good too.  Friendly service and very inexpensive.  Good little find.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Wonton was good, even though is a small restaurant. Services are awesome and fast, one of my best restaurant. I know the people there too.
author: C T.

description: Simple and excellent.  Perfect for a quick, good meal while wandering Chinatown.  Dry noodles with spicy sauce was unique and quite tasty.  Be ready to share a table of you are a party of 2.
author: Justin G.

description: Landed here thanks to yelp, it's clean and the food is delicious. Had Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce and dumpling soup, it was fast and good! Also the place is very clean and personnel is nice. I will come back for sure!
author: cristian p.

description: What you get here is good food and good service. The decor is spartan, and the menu limited, but you will leave here pleased with the price, quantity, and quality.
author: Bill F.

description: Pretty solid wonton soup with a really light, delicious broth! You can also see the kitchen staff and one of their sons making the wontons and dumplings from scratch pretty often!
author: Kim L.

description: Cheap, delicious wonton soup. I like the wontons more than the thin noodles. I do wish the menu had a few more options so I could actually get full, but this place is awesome for a hearty snack!
author: Gina C.

description: It's nice to take a break from normal SF prices for a meal. Bowl of noodles and dumplings were $4 and change. Overall quality was decent, broth was good, could have used more veggies, and more noodles for that matter.
author: Steve T.

description:
Excellent -- this place is clean, and you can watch the family that owns the place make dumplings. 

I loved the beef brisket wonton noodle soup (delicious, juicy beef, 4-5 shrimp/pork wontons, and of course noodles and broth) as well as the bok choy with oyster sauce. The chicken in the chicken congee is so tender; flavors include scallion and ginger. 

All these dishes are under $5. There are no crowds and the restaurant is clean. The feeling of Chinatown with more modernity and less chaos.
author: Zelda Z.

description:
Simple food done well. Had the wonton noodle soup, the brisket and tripe. As good as I have had anywhere around in asia etc. 

If I lived in SF, this would be one of my regular haunts.
author: Ian L.

description: This place was amazing!!!! The brisket, wonton, and noodle soup with Chinese broccoli was delicious and only $5. The Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce was also very yummy. $15 for 2 people for dinner can't be beat.
author: Sarah K.

description: Wonton dumpling is puffy with pork n shrimp! But not the best I've had. The egg noodles are soft and yet crunchy! This is what u look for in egg noodles! Price is decent! Good food! Recommended!
author: Larry W.

description:
went in for the wonton soup. ended up getting the wonton noodle soup. the restaurant has been kept clean. that feeling of freshness is present compared to some divey chinese places.

the bowl is eq. to a small bowl of pho from kevins. served with 6-7 shrimp/pork wontons, a portion of thin egg noodles, and a branch of gai lon.

the broth was very delicious, having a heavy chicken flavor, light on the sodium, but richness from a salmon head. i did not sense any msg or boullion. 

the wontons were delicious, and the noodles were just generic egg noodles. 

for $4.30 this bowl of soup was awesome, light, and filling

definately my go to for wonton soup in the northbeach/ chinatown area
author: Brandon K.

description:
Had the roast duck wonton noodles - good
Beef tendon tossed noodles - good
Pig feet tossed noodles - good
Avg prices around $4-$6 + decent portions = great :)
Family business where the Owner is serving you with a smile is a plus
author: J W.

description: Nice to have a clean place to have some wonton noodle soup in C-town.  Been here a few times and they are consistently fast, have friendly service, and good food all without barely denting the wallet.  I tried the beef brisket wonton noodle soup, pig's feet noodle soup, and dry noodles.  All are good, but from the first time I've been there I always order the kidney and liver appetizer.  It has the perfect amount of flavor in the sauce and is so good with the jalepeno slivers and onions they serve it with.
author: Eric T.

description: My daughter's friend wanted to eat Chinese noodles or soup so we decided, based on the reviews this place received on Yelp, to give this place a try.  Yin Du Wonton Noodle is a real gem.  The food is delicious, the portions just right, and the price very reasonable.  My daughter and her friend ordered the wonton noodle soup and asked to have the rice noodles instead of the thin noodles - both were very pleased with their meal.  The rest of our family ordered the beef brisket noodle with vegetable - it too was very delicious.  Our only suggestion, if you would like more vegetables order a side of the Chinese broccoli or the bokchoy.
author: Raquel A.

description: Food was delicious and service was fast and good even though menu was limited. You have to pay in cash. It is a great place for a quick lunch. I highly recommend their wonton dry noodle, wonton beef noodle, and wonton soup!
author: Ying S.

description:
Great little place for wonton (mostly meat) noodle (with/without) soup, congee or rice plates...this place is well worth the try!

Clean, fresh, simple and quick.
author: do i.

description: Had the congee! It was beautiful. Clean and organized, the owner runs a tight shop. Everything was excellent.
author: Brett W.

description: Great beef brisket wonton noodle soup loved it! My son couldn't stop eating it and very friendly service!
author: MiniD D.

description: Cheap good fast. Lots of different combos you can order from. Place has a lot of seats. Hard to find parking tho!
author: Cindy L.

description: Great noodles - they are nice and crunchy just the way they're supposed to be! Soup is delicious and not over seasoned with msg. Found a new spot for wonton noodles for sure! Correction on business hours though. They close at 7:30 everyday. Not at 8. And they will turn you away even if you walk in at 7:33pm :(
author: lincy s.

description: Best beef brisket I've ever had! Rice noodle and wonton are also good. The owners are always nice and work really hard. When it gets busy they would seat you with other people to share a table... well it's Chinatown. Cash only
author: Li F.

description: Had wonton noodle soup. The wonton and noodles were ok. I prefer wonton with more shrimp in it and noodles to be slightly crunchy.
author: Linda Y.

description: This place is excellent. It does exactly what it sets out to do, and it does it very well. Cheap, clean, delicious. Friendly service too. Get the wonton noodle soup with beef brisket if you don't know what to order.
author: YUP K.

description: The best service ever! Unexpected for a noodle place this small. The beef brisket with noodle, noodle soup or rice is really tasty! If it wasnt for the long drive, we would have ordered food to go too!!!
author: Leah G.

description: The best thing on the menu here is the congee. I always get the fish or the pork+egg. There is a small section of dishes that doesn't seem like it belongs, something about Sichuan noodles... I think it tastes rather sweet and somehow strange. But the boyfriend likes it so I guess they know what they're doing.  For me this is one of those restaurants that will be the best place for one thing.  I'll come eat here whenever it's just too cold in San Francisco and I want to take the chill off with a big bowl of congee
author: Marcus L.

description: the food is good..but I'm not happy with the portion. I'm still feeling hungry after eating a bowl of wonton noddle soup..sad....
author: Sonnia A.

description: A great place to stop by for quick lunch. The wonton noodle taste so yummy and cheap and services is efficient. Nothing to complain about. Perhaps the portion might be a bit too small but at least I left there with my stomach fulfilled. A big plus for their open kitchen so I don't have to worry about the cleanliness of food preparation especially when it comes to Chinatown. Love to support small business!
author: Ella T.

description: I am not a noodle expert by any means.  After reading the reviews here, I decided to try this place out.  I ordered the brisket and noodle soup. The brisket was fatty and tough and the broth had a horrible flavoring.  I could not eat it, I paid and left.  The service was quick and courteous and the restaurant was clean.  But from now on, I will just go to the Ramen Underground around the corner when I want soup. So much better.
author: Wendy W.

description: Delicious bowl of soup for a good price. I got the brisket wonton noodle bowl for $4.75. It also comes with a bit of bok choy. I really liked the broth and noodles. The wontons and bok choy were pretty good as well. The brisket I found to be very disappointing. It was tough yet pretty fatty. A good meal anyway, but next time I'm going with no brisket.
author: John B.

description: $5 bowl of won ton noodle soup basically sums it up.  The broth was tasty and not overly salty, with quality egg noodles and hand rolled won tons to boot.  With tax, it came out to about $5.50.  I woudln't say that the noodle soup blew my mind, but it was solid, tasty, and was a cheap, satisfying lunch.  If the portions were bigger, I'm sure I would be a regular.  But then again, you get what you pay for, and I felt the deal was more than fair.
author: Alan C.
